tgt_text.3085: Enter a procession of Persian Elders forming the Chorus.]THIS drama, founded upon the Persian War, and pro­ duced only seven years after its termination (B.C. 472), is invested with peculiar interest, not only as the earliest Æschylean drama which has come down to us, but also as our earliest extant Greek history, the first recorded recitation of Herodotus having taken place at the great Panathenæa.
tgt_text.3087: It ex­ hibits, moreover, the same principles of dramatic art, and the same conceptions respecting the divine govern­ ment which characterise the purely imaginative pro­ ductions of the " warrior-bard."
tgt_text.3088: For its full apprecia­ tion we must endeavour to realise the magnitude of the struggle which it commemorates, together with the momentous consequences to Hellas and to the world which resulted from the Hellenic victory.
tgt_text.3089: About eighty years before the battle of Salamis (fought B.C. 480) the Persians had made their first appearance in history, when, under their leader.
tgt_text.3090: Cyrus, they overthrew the empire of the Medes (B.C. 559).
tgt_text.3091: Within this comparatively brief interval they had brought under subjection not only the native peoples of Asia, but also large areas of Europe and Africa.
tgt_text.3092: At the time of our drama their empire ex­ tended southward over Egypt to Cyrenaica, while to the north it comprised Maritime Thrace, Pæonca, and apparently Macedonia, as far as the borders of Thessaly, besides nearly all the islands of the Ægean, north of Krete and cast of Eubœa.
tgt_text.3093: Their ambition expanded with their conquests, till, at length, they aspired to universal dominion.
tgt_text.3094: "The conquest of Greece was represented by Xerxes as carrying with it that of all Europe, so that the Persian empire would become co­ extensive with the Æther of Zeus, and the limits of the Sun's course.
tgt_text.3096: upon which this colossal empire was based was that of the despotic force of personal will, involving obligation of universal personal service, especially in war.
tgt_text.3097: During the expedition of Xerxes the tributaries of the Persian king were virtually slaves, working under the lash, and driven on to the charge in battle with the scourge.
tgt_text.3098: The profound humiliation of the subject peoples is forcibly depicted by the Chorus, in the ode wherein they lament the overthrow of the Persian power (v. 58G).
tgt_text.3099: Meanwhile, in the heart of Hellas, a new phase of political life had been developed;
tgt_text.3100: Athens I ad thrown off the yoke of her tyrants, tho Pisistratids, and the world saw, for the first time, a state composed of free and equal citizens.
tgt_text.3101: The revolution of Kleisthenes bad established the principles of free speech and equal law, while as yet this now-born liberty had not degene­ rated into licence.
tgt_text.3102: Adverting to the Athenian cou­ stitution at the time when the Persians made their attack on Hellas, Plato says, " Reverence was then our queen and mistress, and made us willing to live in obedience to the laws."
tgt_text.3103: The strength of patriotic sentiment generated by the new constitution inspired the amazing courage required in the Athenians to encounter the hitherto unconquered hosts of Persia ;
tgt_text.3104: upon the plain of Marathon they triumphed, and their glorious victory arrested, for a time, the encroachments of the Persian king.
tgt_text.3105: His son Xerxes undertook to avenge the disaster which had befallen the Persian arms:
tgt_text.3106: after enormous preparations, he set forth on his expedition, at the head of an army composed of forty-six different nations, each with its distinct national costume and local leaders, while eight other nations furnished the fleet.
tgt_text.3107: Well might the contemporary world be overawed by the spectacle of so prodigious an armament, and regard the cause of Hellenic independence as desperate.
tgt_text.3108: The victory of Salamis shattered the power of the barbarians, and changed the destiny of the world. " ' Let there be light!' said Liberty, And, like sunrise from the sea, Athens arose.
tgt_text.3109: "In celebration of the victory thus achieved by struggling and triumphant freedom, and in honour of the city of Pallas, which had won immortal glory at Salamis, Æschylus composed his drama of The Persians.'
tgt_text.3110: It has been justly remarked that " Æschylus is the prophet of Greek tragedy." "
tgt_text.3111: A single episode, a single generation, was insufficient for the display of the dependence of life upon life, and the moral infinitude of action which it was his design to exhibit.
tgt_text.3112: Thus he habitually composed groups of three connected plays, which gave full scope for the development of thought and work.
tgt_text.3114: *Unfortunately, we possess only the second member of the trilogy, which, consisting of three separate dramas, severally entitled, Phineus, The Persians, and Glaukos, ╇ appears to have been known among the ancients by the general name of ' The Persians.'
tgt_text.3116: the Satyric drama of " Prometheus, the Fire-kindler."
tgt_text.3117: Though the second member of this trilogy is alone based upon history, while the first and third, together with the Satyric drama, draw their materials from mythological sources, it appears almost certain that these apparently in­ congruous elements constituted together one grand poetic whole;
tgt_text.3118: the leading idea giving unity to the detached dramas being the struggle between Asia and Europe, which, originating in the dim ages of my­ thology, had at length culminated in the triumph of Hellas over the non-Hellenic races.
tgt_text.3119: In the same manner Herodotus has based his history upon the notion of a primeval enmity subsisting between the Hellenes and the nations of the East.
tgt_text.3120: This apparent incongruity vanishes when we remember that the con­ temporaries of Æschylus cherished the firmest belief in the existence of their legendary heroes, whose pro­ tection and assistance were continually invoked, while their appearance on the scene of action, with super­ human stature and imposing mien, was hailed as an omen of victory.
tgt_text.3121: Æschylus has, moreover, in the second member of the trilogy, so treated the events of contemporary history as to bring them into harmony with the occurrences of the mythical past, invested, as it was, in the popular imagination, with a halo of glory and sublimity.
tgt_text.3122: This was rendered possible by the remoteness of Persia, which was selected as the scene of the drama;
tgt_text.3123: by the gorgeous splendour which surrounded Oriental life;
tgt_text.3124: by the vastness of the armies assembled under the sceptre of the great king, together with the strangeness of the barbaric physiognomy and costume.
tgt_text.3125: "These, exaggerated to still greater proportions in the popular imagination, produced an impression of dim and indefinite greatness not unlike that in which the midst of timo veiled tho heroes of mythology.
tgt_text.3127: *Another feature of tho Æschylean ago is the im­ portanco attached to prophecy, which, as we learn from Herodotus, not unfrequently determined the judgments of men, both Greeks and Asiatics;
tgt_text.3128: which also we find employed by our poet as tho most convenient link for connecting tho separate members of his trilogies.
tgt_text.3129: Thus, in the Oresteia, tho Agamemnon is connected with the Choephori through Cassandra's prophecy of the vengeance which was speedily to fall upon the guilty pair.
tgt_text.3130: If wo turn now to the drama of ' Tho Persians,' we find the Ghost of Darius referring in tho most emphatic manner to certain ancient oracles (v. 739), of which tho calamities which had befallen the Persians were tho recognised fulfilment.
tgt_text.3131: It has been remarked by Welcker that in this passage allusion is obviously made to something which had been brought before tho minds of tho spectators in tho previous drama, and this hypothesis is confirmed by the prophetic character of Phincus, from whom tho first member of tho trilogy derives its name.
tgt_text.3132: Phincus is represented in mythological story as ono of tho sons of Agènor,† tho father of tho beautiful Europa ;
tgt_text.3133: and it is roleted of Agènor by Ovid, and other classical writers, that ho sent forth his sons in quest of their sister, whose abduction by Zeus was represented by Persian literati as the first act of the conflict between the Eastern and the Western world:
tgt_text.3134: this version of the Phineus legend would offer, as remarked by Gruppe, an obvious link of connection with the Persian war.
tgt_text.3135: There are other versions of the story which, notwithstanding some discrepancies as to the genealogy of Phineus, and the circumstances of his blindness, agree in investing him with the prophetic character, and in bringing him into connection with the Argo­ nauts, the grand national adventurers of Hellas.
tgt_text.3136: In the single extant fragment of the Æschylean Phineus reference appears to be made to the Harpies:
tgt_text.3137: Phineus, according to the ancient legend, was delivered from the Harpies by the Boreades;
tgt_text.3138: * and it is related by Apollonius (xi. 317) that, after his deliverance, he prophesied, and foretold to the Argonauts the success­ ful issue of their enterprise.
tgt_text.3139: In accordance with the spirit of the age, which linked together the successive conflicts between Europe and Asia, the expedition of the Argonauts, with that of the Hellenes against Ilium, is associated, by Herodotus, with the Persian war :
tgt_text.3140: Æschylus would probably give greater scope to the prophecies of Phineus, and would thus have an opportunity of carrying back the imagination of the audience to the traditionary commencement of the great struggle which had recently been brought to so glorious a termination.
tgt_text.3141: Thus, according to Welcker, the mythological drama of Phineus would form a kind of prophetic prelude to the historical drama of ' The Persians.
tgt_text.3143: Reference has already been made to the tendency of Æschylus to group together a long scries of events, having reference to some connecting principle.
tgt_text.3144: It might therefore excite surprise that, in treating so momentous a subject as the Persian war, lie should have contented himself with celebrating tho battle of Salamis alone, which, however glorious for Athens, left tho fate of Hellas still undecided.
tgt_text.3145: This would be brought home with peculiar force to the Athenians who, only ten months after the retreat of Xerxes, had been obliged to migrate a second time to Salamis, while Athens became onco more the head-quarters of their dreaded too.
tgt_text.3146: Tho victory of Platæa, which insured tho final deliverance of Hellas, would there­ foro bo regarded as second in importance only to Salamis.
tgt_text.3147: Moreover, in tho drama of 'Tho Persians,' tho ghost of Darius alludes to the battle-field of Platæa on which the ruin of the Persian host was to bo con­ summated, as the just punishment inflicted by Zeus upon their impiety and overweening thoughts.
tgt_text.3148: This prophecy alone would suggest the probability of some reference being made to this important victory in the third member of the trilogy, the Glaukos Potnieus.
tgt_text.3149: According to popular tradition Glaukos was a fisher­ man, who became a marine demigod by eating of the divine life-giving herb sown by Kronos:
tgt_text.3150: one version of the legend represents him to have been one of the Argonauts, who, having fallen from his galley, suffered this transformation.
tgt_text.3151: The so-called grotto of Glaukos was situated near the little town of Anthedon in Bœotia :
tgt_text.3152: this marine deity, accompanied by strange monsters of the sea, was accustomed, once a year, to visit the surrounding coasts and islands, and there to prophesy impending calamity.
tgt_text.3153: His approach was anticipated by the fishermen, by whom he was held in peculiar veneration, who also offered sacrifice and prayers to avert the threatened woe.
tgt_text.3154: It is mentioned by Pausanias (ix. 22, 6), that what Pindar and Æschylus heard from the dwellers at Anthedon con­ cerning this marine deity had furnished materials to both poets, and had sufficed to Æschylus for the creation of a drama.
tgt_text.3155: According to Welcker, the extant fragments of this drama seem to indicate that Glaukos describes a voyage which he made from Anthedon to Sicily.
tgt_text.3156: Passing the promontory of Eubœa, the shore of Zeus Kenæus, and the tomb of the unhappy Lichas (frag. 27), he came to Rhegium (frag. 31, 189 ;
tgt_text.3157: Herm. p. 12), and arrived finally at Himera (frag. 28) in Sicily.
tgt_text.3158: In the neighbourhood of this city was fought the battle of Himera, on which occasion the Sicilian Hellenes repulsed tho Carthaginian invaders, whose attack took place simul­ taneously with that of Xerxes upon Hellas.
tgt_text.3159: It is hardly to be supposed that Æschylus would introduce into his drama the name of Himera without com­ memorating a victory, which his contemporary, Pindar (Pyth. i. 152), represents as not inferior in importance to those of Salamis and Platæa, the circumstances of which also were peculiarly susceptible of poetic treat­ ment.
tgt_text.3160: Tho Bœotian sea-god, moreover, would form tho most appropriate herald of tho Bœotian victory, and thius, in his third drama, Æschylus would have tho opportunity of bringing the battles of Himera and Platæa into connection with that of Salamis, which formed the main feature in the Persian trilogy.
tgt_text.3161: Tho plastic art of tho Hellenes illustrates their tendency to regard tho successive victories of Hellas over Oriental barbarism as phases of tho great struggle between the higher and lower elements of civilization, which formed so prominent a feature in their my­ thology.
tgt_text.3162: Thus, in tho temple of Hera, at Mycenæ (Paus. xi. 17, 3), and in that of Zeus at Agrigentum (Diod.
tgt_text.3163: xi. 82), the capture of Ilium was associated with tho overthrow of the giants by tho Olympian gods.*
tgt_text.3164: Their recent splendid victories would doubtless bo similarly regarded by them as the ultimate triumph of civilization over barbarism, brought about by tho intervention of the higher powers.
tgt_text.3165: This conception has found artistic expression in tho beautiful painting on tho so-called Darius vase, "on which the celestial dcities are represented as consoling the terrified Hellas in face of the threatening purposes and preparations of the mighty king of Asia."
tgt_text.3166: Moreover, "out of the gigantic block of Persian marble at Rhamnus, three leagues from Marathon, which the Persians are said to have intended for a trophy, Phidias (also a prophet) created one of the most sublime of the Greek statues of the gods, that of Nemesis, whose stern form and gesture admonished the Greeks:
tgt_text.3168: to God alone belongs the glory !'
tgt_text.3169: "*It may be remarked, in conclusion, that this drama, by the profound humiliation of Xerxes, strikingly enforces the Hellenic principle that the supreme intelligence, which Æschylus invariably identifies with the will of Zeus, cannot suffer any inferior power, human or divine, to overpass its legitimate limits, and thus interfere with the harmonious working of the whole.
tgt_text.3170: At the same time the dignity of the Persian empire is vindicated by the description of the glorious and happy life which the Persians enjoyed under the rule of Darius, which had been forfeited by their impiety in acting in opposition to the divine decrees;
tgt_text.3171: moreover, by introducing the ghost of the mighty king, not only as the stern rebuker of his son's overweening pride, but also as deprecating in the most emphatic manner any subsequent invasion of Hellas, we see, in this early historical drama, an approach to the great principle of classical dramatic art, which finds its perfect fulfilment in the Oresteian trilogy, namely, the final re-establishment of harmony between the contending powers whose collision has formed the main action of the drama.
tgt_text.3172: The Satyric drama, which invariably followed the trilogy, was a relic of the original dithyrambic chorus sung at the festival of Dionysos by groups of Satyrs who followed the chariot of the vintage-god;
tgt_text.3173: it was probably intended to relieve the serious impression produced by the tragedy, and to furnish amusement to the populace.
tgt_text.3174: It is doubtful whether these Satyric pieces were ever in such organic connection with the three dramas which they followed as to justify calling them a tetralogy;
tgt_text.3175: the significance of the " Prometheus," as the concluding member of ' The Persians,' must however be admitted.
tgt_text.3176: Welcker has shown that we must distinguish between "Prometheus tho fire- bringer," and " Prometheus tho fire-kindler;
tgt_text.3177: " the latter being the title of tho Satyric drama in question, which he maintains had reference to tho establishment of the Promethen, the torch-race, at Athens, an artisan festival of which Promethens was regarded as the founder.
tgt_text.3178: The kindling of tho sacred fire might well be hailed as the symbol not only of victory, but also of tho brighter day which had just dawned for tho Hellenic race;
tgt_text.3179: while the association of tho poorer classes, by tho introduction of their favourite festival, would impart to tho drama a peculiarly popular character, and render it tho appropriate expression of tho national enthusiasm.

tgt_text.3838: CHORUS OF THEBAN MAIDENS.ANTIGONE.HERALD,[SCENE.—THEBES, in front of the Acropolis.
tgt_text.3839: The stage, adorned tcith altars and statues of the gods, is occupied by a crowd of Theban citizens.
tgt_text.3840: Enter ETEOCLES with his train.]THE trilogy to which this drama belonged was repre­ sented B.C. 467, five years after* " The Persians," and consisted, as we learn from the Didascalia given in the Medicean manuscript, of Laios, Œdipus, and “The Seven against Thebes," followed by the Satyric drama of the Sphinx.
tgt_text.3841: It has been appropriately styled the dramatic epos of the House of Labdacos, for though the conflicting emotions in the soul of Eteocles are portrayed with true tragic insight, yet in “The Seven," as in “The Persians," narrative so far prepon­ derates over action as to render the treatment of their respective subjects epic rather than dramatic.
tgt_text.3842: In this, as in the other dramas of AEschylus, the aim of the poet is to vindicate the divine government, and to exhibit the ultimate triumph of order and justice.
tgt_text.3843: The principle more especially emphasized, that of divine retribution—“ the key-stone of the universal order "-was embodied by the Greeks in the word Nemesis:
tgt_text.3844: passing from the domain of conscience, it became in later times a divinity, and has been aptly characterized by Bunsen as the “Muse of Justice."
tgt_text.3845: In accordance with her teaching, the eternal laws can never bo violated with impunity:
tgt_text.3846: with sleepless vigilance the dread avenger follows on the track of crime:
tgt_text.3847: for a season, perhaps, no muttering is heard of the coming storm;
tgt_text.3848: but not the less inevitably does punishment eventually overtake the wrongdoer, or his posterity.
tgt_text.3849: Associated with this inexorable law of retribution, the poet, in the Theban tragedy, exhibits the working of those mysterious tendencies to moral evil which, like hereditary disease, not unfrequently accompany the fatal heritage of crime, and which, if not counteracted by the force of personal will, issue in the final destruction of the sin-polluted race.
tgt_text.3850: A brief outline of the hoary legend, the main features of which would doubtless be embodied in the first two members of the trilogy, the Laios and the CEdipus, is essential for the due appreciation of the concluding drama..
tgt_text.3851: The crime of Laios may be regarded as the fatal seed-corn from which he and his descendants reaped a tear-fraught harvest.
tgt_text.3852: This is indicated in the choral ode of " The Seven against Thebes" (v. 737), which it has been truly said strikes the key-note of the drama.
tgt_text.3853: Received as a guest into the house of Pelops, he;

tgt_text.3855: Heedless of tho divine monition, ho, in on evil hour, “begat his proper woe, in Œdipus the parricide " (v. 747).
tgt_text.3856: Laios, in order to evade the oracle which had declared that himself would be slain by any son whom he might beget, caused the infant, as soon as born, to be exposed on Mount Cithæron, the savage scenery of which harmonizes with the dark passages of Hellenic lore with which it is associated.
tgt_text.3857: Here he is found by the herdsmen of Polybos, king of Corinth, who carry him to their master, by whom he is reared as his own child.
tgt_text.3858: When grown to manhood, doubts having been cast upon his descent, he repairs to Delphi, in order to discover the truth as to his parentage.
tgt_text.3859: Warned by the oracle not to return to his country, he proceeds towards Bœotia, and at the spot called the divided way, encounters Laios, whom in a skirmish he slays, not knowing him to be his father.
tgt_text.3860: Pursuing his journey he arrives at Thebes, where, after solving the riddle of the Sphinx, he obtains the kingdom, and marries Jocasta, by whom ho becomes the father of two sons, Eteocles aud Polyneikes, and of two daughters, Antigone and Ismene.
tgt_text.3861: The truth respecting his un­ happy marriage being at length brought to light, he in despair puts out his eyes, and resigns the government to his sons.
tgt_text.3862: They, wishing that the family shame should be concealed from the eyes of men, place him in confinement, and it is related in one fragment of the Thebais, that instead of the shoulder of the victims sacrificed on the altar, they sent him the less honour­ able portions.
tgt_text.3863: This, in his rage, he cast upon the ground, and, at the same time, prayed to the gods that his sons might perish, each by the hand of the other.
tgt_text.3864: Reference appears to be made to this ancient form of the tradition in the Seven (v. 787).
tgt_text.3865: The brothers, fearing lest their father's curse should be fulfilled, make an agreement to reign over the Theban territory in turn, each for the space of a year.
tgt_text.3866: Eteocles, as the elder, reigns first, and at the appointed time Polyneikes comes to demand the sceptre, which his brother refuses to resign.
tgt_text.3867: Polyneikes retires to Argos, and persuades Adrastos, his father-in-law, to assist him to recover the throne.
tgt_text.3868: Accordingly, that prince and fivo other chiefs, accompanied by Polyneikes, march against the Cadmeian city.
tgt_text.3869: With their appearance before the walls the third member of the trilogy opens.
tgt_text.3870: Such, in outline, is the terrible story which ushers in “The Seven against Thebes."
tgt_text.3871: The first tragedy probably ended with the death of Laios, while the wrath of CEdipus, and his curse, twice pronounced against his sons, would doubtless form a principal feature of the second drama.

tgt_text.3873: I cannot but think, however, that wo should misread the poet did wo Imagine that the death of the brothers resulted from the Inevitable operation of their father's curse.
tgt_text.3874: Eteocles, though courageous, is full of in­ satiablo rage, and instead of yielding to tho pathetic pleading of the Chorus, exults in the prospect of fratricide;
tgt_text.3875: while Polyneikes is represented as sharing the malignant hatred of his brother (v. 632).
tgt_text.3876: Eteocles, moreover, by retaining the sovereignty, violates the claims of justice;
tgt_text.3877: and Polyneikes, by seeking to regain it with the assistance of an invading host, is guilty of impiety towards his country:
tgt_text.3878: thus the death of the brothers, through mutual slaughter, is the penalty due to their respective wrongdoing, and, as such, offers no violence to our sense of justice.
tgt_text.3879: King Apollo, it is true, the awful Seventh, is represented as taking his station at the seventh gate, and avenging upon the sons of Œdipus the ancient transgression of Laios;
tgt_text.3880: at the same time the poet makes us feel that they have themselves succumbed to the evil tendencies inherent in the race, and thus it is that their father's curse has exercised its dread ascendency over their destiny.
tgt_text.3881: Had the trilogy terminated with the death of the brothers such a catastrophe would have violated an essential canon of classical dramatic art, which requires the final reconciliation of the principles brought into collision during the action of the play.
tgt_text.3882: These principles, in the drama before us, are-duty to the family, and duty to the State;
tgt_text.3883: the harmonious action of which is necessary to the well-being of society.
tgt_text.3884: Thus it would appear that the decree of the senate respecting the burial of the royal brothers, which has been regarded as a dramatic blunder on the part of Æschylus, is in fact essential for bringing about a satis­ factory dénouement.
tgt_text.3885: When, in spite of the prohibition of the senate, Antigone proclaims her heroic determi­ nation to inter her brother:
tgt_text.3886: she claims our warmest sympathy and admiration :
tgt_text.3887: had she stood alone, her heroism and sisterly affection would have offered a refreshing relief to the deadly hatred of tho brothers.
tgt_text.3888: The action of the Chorus gives, however, a deeper significance to the episode.
tgt_text.3889: The Chorus, it must be remembered, represents in the Greek theatre the moral conscience of the age, in its most elevated form ;
tgt_text.3890: * a character strikingly exemplified in the drama before us.
tgt_text.3891: At the commencement, indeed, they are timid Theban women, who, vividly realizing the brutal outrages offered to women after the capture of a beleaguered city, are possessed by overwhelming fear.
tgt_text.3892: As the drama develops, however, they gradually assume a loftier tone;
tgt_text.3893: the words of expostulation addressed by them to Eteocles are full of piety and wisdom:
tgt_text.3894: when, therefore, one half of the Chorus follow, with Antigone, the body of Polyneikes, and the other half, with Ismene, that of Eteocles, wo may understand that the poet intended thus to recognise the equal sacredness of the principles respectively repre­ sented by the sisters, namely, allegiance to the holy tio of kindred-blood, and fealty to the State-the object, in Greek civilization, of tho most ardent patriotism.
tgt_text.3895: The great Theban trilogy, as remarked by Bunsen, begins and ends with deeds of horror ;
tgt_text.3896: but as the last and heaviest judgment is executed, gracious images of the future surround the bodies of tho slain ;
tgt_text.3897: tho devoted heroism displayed by the Theban women " is a living pledge for the moral order < f the world,” and offers a spectacle commensurate in grandeur with the darker features of the drama.
tgt_text.3898: Very interesting is the protest thus offered by the pro­ phet-bard of antiquity against that want of respect for women, and that jealousy of their participation in the functions of men, which find such frequent expression in Greek literature, and which are embodied in the insolent language addressed by Eteocles to the Chorus at the commencement of the drama (v. 169).
tgt_text.3899: Such examples as that of the Theban women may have inspired the wise utterance of Plato, who declares that for the legislator to leave women without educa­ tion, and without sufficient scope for their energies, is materially to cripple the power of the State.

tgt_text.4634: THE combat between the Titans and the Olympian Gods, issuing in the triumph of the latter, constitutes, as Hegel remarks, the central fact of Hellenic my­ thology.
tgt_text.4635: This hoary legend may be regarded as symbolizing in the physical universe the emergence of order out of chaos, while in the history of religious thought it marks a period of transition, characterized mainly by the metamorphosis of the nature-powers, the objects of men's earlier worship, into the humanized divinities of Hellas, involving the recognized supremacy of the higher over the lower elements of being.
tgt_text.4636: One phase of this struggle is treated by AEschylus in the drama of the Eumenides;
tgt_text.4637: there the hoary god­ desses, the dark vengeance-powers of the primeval world, are brought into harmonious subordination to Pallas Athena, the impersonation of the wisdom and benignity of Zeus.
tgt_text.4638: Another aspect of the conflict formed the subject of the Promethean trilogy, which set forth the relation between the finite and the supreme will, in their antagonism and their reconciliation.
tgt_text.4639: Among the grand ideals bequeathed to the world by Hellenic genius there is none, perhaps, which has more deeply impressed the poetic imagination than the much­ enduring Titan;
tgt_text.4640: none, certainly, which has for a longer period coloured the stream of philosophic thought.
tgt_text.4641: The Promethean myth, it must be remembered, was not the invention of either Hesiod or Æschylus;
tgt_text.4642: its root, as Bunsen remarks, is older than the Hellenes themselves.
tgt_text.4643: Even at the present day, the legend, in its rudest form, may be traced among the Iranian tribes of the Caucasus, while in our western world it has in­ spired the genius of more than one great poet of modern times.
tgt_text.4644: The three dramas of which the trilogy consisted arc believed to have been “ Prometheus, the Fire-bringer,” " Prometheus Bound," and " Prometheus Unbound," of which the second has alone survived.-
tgt_text.4645: Prometheus there appears as the champion and benefactor of mail­ kind, whose condition, at the close of the Titanic age, is depicted as weak and miserable in the extreme :

tgt_text.4649: ”Zeus, it is said, proposed to annihilate these puny ephemerals, and to plant upon the earth a new race in their stead.
tgt_text.4650: Prometheus represents himself as having frustrated this design, and as being consequently sub­ jected, for tho sake of mortals, to the most agonising pain, inflicted by the remorseless cruelty of Zens.
tgt_text.4651: We have thus the Titan, the symbol of finite reason and free will, depicted as the sublime philanthropist, while Zeus, the supreme deity of Hellas, is portrayed as the cruel and obdurate despot, a character peculiarly re­ volting to Athenian sentiment.
tgt_text.4652: The attempt to explain this apparent anomaly has given rise to a variety of theories and speculations.
tgt_text.4653: It is urged by some that at the time of Æschylus so sharp a line was drawn, in the minds of educated men, between religion and mythology, that the latter was accepted simply as poetical imagery, and was employed by the poet without any definite moral aim.
tgt_text.4654: Others imagine, with Welcker, that Æschylus, as a contemporary of Zenophanes, and one initiated into the Eleusinian mysteries, maintained an antagonistic attitude towards the traditional creed, and that in the Promethean trilogy he seized the opportunity to enter his protest against it, by representing the head of the Olympian system under so revolting an aspect.
tgt_text.4655: It must be remembered, how­ ever, that the Athenian drama formed part of a solemn religious festival, celebrated by the entire population, and that the popular theology was intertwined with the national and political life not only of Athens, but of Hellas.
tgt_text.4656: The magnificent statues of Pallas Athena and of Olympian Zeus, executed at enormous cost by Phidias, the contemporary of Æschylus, were doubtless regarded by the multitudes assembled at the national festivals as symbols of divine and very awful realities;
tgt_text.4657: and if we turn to the remaining dramas of the poet we find his delineation of these divinities in harmony with this conception.
tgt_text.4658: Zeus, more especially, is represented as uniting in himself the sublimest attributes of deity.
tgt_text.4659: The Chorus, in their solemn invocation (Ag. 160), lay peculiar stress upon the name of Zeus, as the supreme deity, the prime source of consolation and of wisdom.
tgt_text.4660: He is elsewhere portrayed as the almighty ruler (Sup. 795), who by ancient law directs destiny (Sup. 655), and without whose will nothing is accom­ plished for mortals (Sup. 804).
tgt_text.4661: He is invoked as king of kings, most blest among the blest, of powers on high most perfect power (Sup. 519).
tgt_text.4662: He is likewise apo­ strophised as father, creator, king, supreme artificer, wielding no delegated sway, and whose deed is prompt as his word to execute the designs of his deep-coun­ selling mind (Sup. 587).
tgt_text.4666: the punisher of over­ weening pride (Per. 822);
tgt_text.4667: the upholder of tho righteous law of retribution (Ag. 154).
tgt_text.4668: Many more passages of a similar character might bo adduced, from which it would appear that the poet, though not emancipated from the errors and limitations of Polytheism, had, nevertheless, risen to the sublime ideal of one supremo ruler, whose righteous will was identified with tho eternal decrees of destiny.
tgt_text.4669: Instead of placing himself in antagonism with tho popular religion, ho seems rather, as the prophet of Polytheism, to havo striven to elevate the popular conception of Zeus, and of tho other Hellenie divinities, more especially Apollo and Pallas Athena, who are represented in tho Oresteia as tho willing but subordinate executors of their father's will.
tgt_text.4670: It seems improbable that in the Promethean trilogy alone he should assume an attitude towards the popular religion utterly irreconcilable with the tendencies manifested in his remaining works;
tgt_text.4671: the apparent con­ tradiction has doubtless arisen from the loss of the concluding drama.
tgt_text.4672: I agree with those critics who think that if we possessed it we should see the majesty of Zeus fully vindicated, and reconciliation established between the contending powers.
tgt_text.4673: As it seems unreasonable to accept, without quali­ fication, the gross picture of Zeus as represented, in the extant drama, by his exasperated adversary, Prometheus, so we must look elsewhere for the true ground of the antagonism subsisting between him and the Olympian divinities, all of whom are arrayed against him.
tgt_text.4674: Though the Promethean myth, as related by Plato, in the “ Protagoras," differs in many essential features from the version of Æschylus, yet the fundamental thought there embodied is so completely in harmony with the teaching of the prophet-bard, that it may be referred to as, perhaps, throwing light upon the moral significance of the trilogy.
tgt_text.4675: In the “ Protagoras " a distinction is drawn between the wisdom which minis­ ters to physical well-being, and political wisdom which enables men to live in organized communities.
tgt_text.4676: Pro­ metheus is represented as having endowed men with the former, but as unable to invest them with the latter, which involved the exercise of justice, and was under the special guardianship of Zeus.
tgt_text.4677: Now it is this quality of justice which was bestowed upon mortals by Zeus that Æschylus extols with peculiar emphasis.

tgt_text.4717: Nowhere are the noble and the repulsive features of Hellenic mythology more remarkably associated than in the numerous legends which gather round the person of Herakles.

tgt_text.4762: In concluding this very inadequate study of a great subject, I will allude, in a few words, to the theory propounded by Professor Kuhn, with reference to the Promethean myth.*
tgt_text.4763: He considers the name of the Titan to be derived from the Sanscrit word Pramantha, the instrument used for kindling fire.
tgt_text.4764: The root mand, or manth, implies rotatory motion, and the word manthami, used to denote the process of fire-kindling, acquired the secondary sense of snatching away ;
tgt_text.4765: hence we find another word of the same stock, pramatha, signi­ fying theft.
tgt_text.4766: The word manthami passed into the Greek language, and became the verb manthanô, to learn;
tgt_text.4767: that is to say to appropriate knowledge ;
tgt_text.4769: Prometheus, the fire-bringer, is the Pramantha personified, and finds his prototype in the Aryan Matarisvan, a divine or semi-divino per­ sonage, closely associated with Agni, the fire-god of the Vedas.
tgt_text.4770: We have thus another curious instance of the common elements which may be detected in the Vedic and Hellenic mythology, while the development of the Promethean myth affords an instructive illustra­ tion of the mode in which words, originally having reference to natural phenomena, gradually became invested with new and more spiritual significance when transplanted to the soil of Hellas.

tgt_text.5630: INTRODUCTION.THE trilogy to which this drama belonged, like that of which " The Seven against Thebes" formed the con­ cluding member, was founded upon an ancient epic, by an unknown author.
tgt_text.5631: Of this poem little is known, except that it contained five thousand five hundred verses, and bore the title of " The Danaides.
tgt_text.5632: "The story which it embodied appealed powerfully to that passion for legendary genealogies which formed such a striking feature of the Grecian character.
tgt_text.5633: Alleged descent from a common ancestor was the bond of union between the members of every Grecian com­ munity, great or small;
tgt_text.5634: and as this legendary personage was usually of divine or semi-divine origin, even the humblest citizen thus felt himself brought into more or less direct filiation with the gods.
tgt_text.5635: The divine element thus, according to the popular conception, incarnated in humanity, culminated in the great national hero, Herakles, " the most renowned and ubiquitous of all the semi-divine personages worshipped by the Hellenes "-the only mortal who, from a life of toil and suffering on earth, was admitted to the god­ head, and received into the society of Olympos.
tgt_text.5636: His descendants, moreover, the Herakleids, associated with the Dorians in the conquest of the Peloponnesus, were glorified in the popular imagination as the founders of the great Dorian cities of Argos, Sparta, and Messenia, and as the introducers in those localities of a new social order.
tgt_text.5637: Peculiar interest thus attaches to Io, the progenitrix of Herakles, and to the birth of her off­ spring, Epaphos, an event celebrated in such glowing strains by the chorus of Suppliants (v. 580).
tgt_text.5638: *In thus veiling the grosser features of the Io legend, as popularly conceived, while, at the same time, investing it with a more spiritual meaning, Æsehylus appears not only as the great creative poet, but also as tho true prophet of his generation.
tgt_text.5639: The numerous legends of which the story of Io may be regarded as a typical example embodied, in a vulgar form, tho idea that it was only through association with the divino principle that man could rise to his true ideal as man.
tgt_text.5640: Tho poet seizes upon this idea, separates it from the grosser elements of the popular symbol, and extols the benignity of Zeus in thus seeking fellowship with mortals—giving prominence to the idea that through this agency alone the human race was raised to a higher level, physical and moral, than it could otherwise havo attained.
tgt_text.5641: Tho introductory character of " Tho Suppliants" has been inferred from tho extreme simplicity of the plot, and from other considerations;
tgt_text.5642: accordingly, it is now generally regarded as forming the first member of a trilogy of which the succeeding dramas were " The Egyptians," and " The Danaides," both of which have been lost.
tgt_text.5643: Though deficient in dramatic interest, this piece is characterized by the remarkable beauty of the choral odes, which, from their sublime simplicity, and from the high conception which they embody of Zeus, as the supreme and omnipotent ruler, remind us occa­ sionally of the Hebrew psalms.
tgt_text.5644: It must be remembered, moreover, that, at the time of Æschylus, the national legends had not yet lost their hold upon the popular belief, and accordingly mythical events, such as the arrival of the Danaides in Argos, were considered not only as having influenced the subsequent destinies of Greece, but also as having been brought about by the inscrutable counsels of Zeus;
tgt_text.5645: the unfolding of whose designs, through the medium of tragedy, was regarded as the highest function of the poet.
tgt_text.5646: The ancient legend tells of the strife between the sons of Belos ;
tgt_text.5647: how Danaos was driven from his home by Ægyptos, who usurped his throne;
tgt_text.5648: how the latter sought to force the Danaides to marry his sons, and how Athena herself exhorted Danaos to flee with his daughters to the land of Io.
tgt_text.5649: The introductory drama opens with their arrival, in the character of suppliants, at Argos, and is founded upon the protection accorded to them by the Argives and their king, Pelasgos:
tgt_text.5650: the appearance of the Egyptian herald, at the conclusion of the play, toge­ ther with his forcible attempt to carry off the suppliants, prepares the spectator for the arrival of the Egyptian pursuers in the succeeding drama.
tgt_text.5651: Attention has been called to the picturesque beauty of the opening scene, where, holding in their bands their wool-wreathed myrtle boughs, and arrayed in white apparel, which formed a striking contrast to their swarthy limbs, the suppliants grouped themselves under the statues of the gods :
tgt_text.5652: they would, moreover, be regarded with peculiar interest as wanderers from tho valley of the Nile, " the wondrous river fed with snow," upon whose fountains no human eye had been permitted to gaze.

tgt_text.6321: Since hither sailing, eager in pursuit, In swiftly-wafted ships our foes have sped.
tgt_text.6322: 1030Whate'er is fated that must sure befal;
tgt_text.6323: The will of Zeus, almighty, absolute, None may transgress.
tgt_text.6324: May wedlock find at last, As to full many women in the past, For us a happy issue.
tgt_text.6328: Cure seekest thou for cureless ill.
tgt_text.6329: 1040But certes thou the future canst not read.
tgt_text.6330: How search of Zeus the hidden will ?
tgt_text.6333: What Heaven ordaineth, that with patience bear.
tgt_text.6334: lOGOFrom us this wedlock's hateful hostile rito May sovereign Zeus avert, of old who freed To from bale,-the while her frenzied speed With healing hand he checked, working with gracious might.
tgt_text.6336: He with victory crown our woman's side!
tgt_text.6337: The better part, though blent with ill, be mine!
tgt_text.6338: O'er our just cause may Justice' self preside, Responsive to my prayer, through saving-arts divine!

tgt_text.6365: My present belief is that we get the poet's sense by ’Ιθεία Διὸς ἐν παναληθεῖ .... which means, " In the straight line of Jove, though drawn with perfect accuracy, the heart's desire of Jove is not easy to trace."

tgt_text.6372: The little word καὶ offends me, and suggests that καὶ διάνοιαν should possibly be παιδὸς ἄνοιαν.

tgt_text.6387: The first two lines should change places, and the fourth should be first.
tgt_text.6389: τηρὸν is difficult to justify and difficult to condemn ;

tgt_text.6405: πιθοῦ τε, καὶ πανεχθῶν I ἄλευσον ἀνδρῶν ὕβριν.528. γενοῦ πολυμνήστωρ cannot be right.
tgt_text.6406: Dindorf prints πολυμνῆστορ metri causâ, I suppose, rightly regarding ὕβριν as a pyrrhic in the strophe.
tgt_text.6407: Apparently for πολυμνήστωρ we need an accusative epithet of αἶνον, and for γενοῦ a geni­ tive or dative, such as γόνου or γονῇ (not γένους, for that occurs twice besides in the sentence).
tgt_text.6408: I doubtfully propose νέωσον εὄφρον’ αἶνον I γόνου πολύμνηστον.
tgt_text.6409: In the next line, τοι must be either interpreted σοὶ, I suppose, or changed into σοί.’ʹΕνοικοι seems to be for the prosaic ἔποικοι, settlers.
tgt_text.6411: Surely ὕδωρ τὸ Νείλου ought to be ὕδωρ τε Νείλου.
tgt_text.6412: The poet says that the wind of the desert (τυφῶ μένος) and the water of Nile come upon the snow-fed fields of Egypt.
tgt_text.6413: Like Herodotus, he supposed that snow, melting in the highlands of Abyssinia, kept the Nile full through the summer.558.
tgt_text.6414: θείας is clearly wrong, yet it is hard to believe θυιὰς right.
tgt_text.6415: My last thought is δαλὴς ζαθέαισον.574.
tgt_text.6416: I protest against rendering ἕρμα, ballast, as an utter monstrosity, and suggest that it means gem, germ.
tgt_text.6417: Compare Iliad, iv. 177, and ἕρματα for gems, ἕρμος, a necklace.
tgt_text.6419: The logic of τίς γὰρ proves that the previous lines assert the progeny to have been Jupiter's;
tgt_text.6420: hence Zηνὸς must be predicate, and τὸ δὴ cannot possibly be right.
tgt_text.6421: I propose to change it to τόδε.628.
tgt_text.6422: ἀρότοις ἐνἄλλοις implies that aporos in a literal sense has been named in the previous lines:
tgt_text.6423: I think, therefore, that ἄχορον has somehow come in place of the word ἄροτος.
tgt_text.6424: In the antistrophe, for πράκτορά τε σκόπον, which is certainly wrong, I would suggest πράκτ
tgt_text.6426: Paley well changes τὼς to γᾶς.674.
tgt_text.6427: I like the Aldine reading ἐπιβώμαν better than ἐπὶ βωμῶν or βωμοῖς.
tgt_text.6428: We probably all adopt μοῦσαν θείατ, with Ahrens and Hermann, for μοῦσαι θεαί τε.678-680.

tgt_text.6430: yet it may be corrected in more ways than one.

tgt_text.6433: This is the poet's ideal of a well-tempered free state. "
tgt_text.6434: Let the folk reserve honours (public offices) for the virtuous, and let a magistracy of common counsel stablish the city by previous delibera­ tions."
tgt_text.6436: For αἰσί­ μοισι the old text has ἀτιμίας, which is manifestly wrong.979.

tgt_text.6441: that is, ἐρᾷ (φιλει) κωλύουσα, “ she loves to hinder the unripe from abiding safe.

tgt_text.6: Königspallast zu Argos, vorn mit Götterstatuen geschmückt.
tgt_text.7: Auf dem Borplatz der Altar des Apollon;
tgt_text.8: über dem Gebäude die Aussicht rechts auf die Stadt, links auf die Ferne und das Meer.
tgt_text.9: Wenn der Vorhang sinkt, sieht man auf dem flachen Dach des Pal­ lasteS den Wächter, liegend aufgestützt, hinausspähen.Die Götter bitt' ich um ein Ende dieser Müh'n
tgt_text.10: Das ganze Jahr schon, da ich wachend hier vom Dach Des Atridenshclosses, wie ein Hund richtaufgestützt, Der stillen Sterne Nachtgesellschaft angeshcaut, Und, die den Menschen Sommer bringen und Winterzeit, Die lichten Herrscher, die im Aether strahlenden Gestirne, wann ihr Aufgang ist, ihr Niedergang.
tgt_text.11: Und wieder späh' ich nach des Flammenzeichens Schein, Dem Strahl des Feuers, das Bericht von Jlion Und Siegesbotschaft bringen soll;
tgt_text.12: denn also heischt In sichrer Hoffnung meiner Herrin männlich Herz.
tgt_text.13: So lieg' ich hier auf meiner nachtverstörten Streu, Der thaugenäßten, der ein Traum nicht nahen darf, — Es steht ja statt des Schlafes neben mir die Furcht, Fest gar mir schließen könnte die Wimpern Müdigkeit.
tgt_text.14: Und wenn ich ein Lied mir singen oder pfeifen will, Den besten Schlaftrunk für den Wachestörer Schlaf, So wird's ein Klaglied über dieses Hauses Loos, Das nicht wie vordem löblich mehr verwaltet ist.
tgt_text.15: Doch käme jetzt des nächt'gen Botenfeuers Schein, So hätte alle meine Müh' ein glücklich End.
tgt_text.16: (Feuerschein.) O sei gegrüßt mir, Licht der Nacht! taghelle Lust Weckst du in mir, erweckst in Argos weit und breit Festchorgesänge, diesem Glück zu frohem Dank!
tgt_text.18: Agamemnons Gattin will ich es laut verkündigen, Daß schnell ihr Lager sie verlasse, im Pallast Den freudenhellsten Jubel diesem Feuerschein Entgegenjauchze, da die Troerfeste nun Gefallen ist, wie dort der Schein es leuchtend sagt!
tgt_text.19: Dann will ich selbst beim Fest den Vortanz halten;
tgt_text.20: denn Von meiner Herrschaft gutem Wurf nehm' ich ja auch Mein Theil, da mir mein Späh'n die besten Augen warf.
tgt_text.21: — O sei's gewährt mir, meines heimgekehrten Herrn Geliebte Hand zu fassen hier mit dieser Hand!
tgt_text.23: mir verschließt ein golden Schloß Den Mund;
tgt_text.24: das Haus selbst, wenn es sprechen könnte, würd'
tgt_text.26: Denn, der's weiß, mit dem Besprech' ich's gern;
tgt_text.27: für den, der's nicht weiß, weiß ich'S nicht!
tgt_text.30: Eins der Stadt (rechtSher) kommt der Chor Argeiischer Greise.
tgt_text.32: Zehn Jahre nun sind's, Da gen Troja des Priamos mächtiger Feind Menelaos der Fürst, Agamemnon mit ihm, Mit gedoppeltem Thron, mit gedoppeltem Stab Vom Kroniden geehrt, das gewaltige Paar Der Atriden, von hier mit gewappneter Macht Fortzogen zum Streit Mit den tausend Argeiischen Segeln.Voll Zornwuth schrie'n sie gewaltigen Kampf, Wie der Weih' des Gebirges, wenn die Brut ihm geraubt, Sein einsam Nest weithallenden Rufs Unermüdlich umkreist Von der Fittige ruderndem Schlage gewiegt, Der in's Nest bannenden, Der Sorge verwaist um die Jungen.Doch droben ein Gott, ob es Pan, ob es Zeus, Ob Apollon ist, er vernimmt des Geschreis Weithallenden Schmerz um die fehlende Brut;
tgt_text.33: Die Vergelterin schickt Die Erinnys er dem Verruchten.Also zum Gericht Alexanders hat Zeus, So des Gastrechts Hort die Atriden gesandt;
tgt_text.34: So läßt um das männerumbuhlete Weib Unablässigen, gliederzerschmetternden Kampf, Daß ermattend das Knie an den Boden sich stemmt Und die Lanze zerschellt vorkämpfender Reih'n, — So läßt er die Danaer dulden.
tgt_text.37: Es erfüllet sich doch dem Verhängniß nach.
tgt_text.38: Ob er Opfer auch bringt, ob spendet, ob weint, Nicht löscht er den Zorn, den er frevelnd geweckt, Den Zorn um die weihlose Weihe!Doch wir, die der schon hinalternde Leib Damals ausschloß von der Ehre des Zugs, Wir weilen daheim, Die kindische Kraft mit dem Stäbe gestützt;
tgt_text.39: Denn das quellende Mark aufsprossender Kraft In dem Körper des Kindes, dem Greis' ist's gleich:
tgt_text.40: In dem Frühgrün weilet noch Ares nicht;
tgt_text.41: Und wer schon Greis, wem herbstlich die Stirn Sich entlaubet, er wankt dreifüßigen Gang, Nicht kräftiger mehr denn ein kraftlos Kind, Ein tagumirrendes Traumbild.(
tgt_text.42: Während dessen ist aus dem Pallast ein festlicher Zug von Dienerinnen mit Schalen und Krügen auf die Bühne getreten, der sich um die Altäre schaart;
tgt_text.43: dann erscheint im hohen Schmuck die Königin Klytaimnestra, das Opfer zu rüsten und die Gaben für die vershciedenen Altäre zu ver­ theilen.
tgt_text.44: )Doch, Königin, sprich', du des Tyndaros Kind, Klytaimnestra, was ist? was Neues geschah?
tgt_text.45: Auf welches Gerücht, auf wessen Bericht Ist's, daß du die Weihen bereitest?Und den Göttern zumal, den Behütern der Stadt, Himmlischen, Unteren, Und des Markts, des Pallyst's Obwaltern entflammt
tgt_text.46: Für die Feier sich jeglicher Altar.Schon hüben und drüben zum Himmel empor Steigt flackernde Gluth, Von des heiligen Krug's süßtriefendem Guß Mit der Kraft untückischen Zaubers getränkt, Mit der Hofburg köstlichstem Weihöl.So sage davon, was kund schon thun Du mir willst, du mir kannst;
tgt_text.47: So werde du mir der Besorgniß Arzt, Die jetzt mir das Herz bald tückisch beschleicht, Bald wieder, erhellt von dem Opfer, mir lacht, Mir als Hoffnung lacht und die nagende Pein Fortscheucht unlösbaren Sinnens.
tgt_text.48: (Während des folgenden Gesanges der drei Führer verläßt Alytaimnestra, die Opferceremonie von Altar zu Altar zu verrichten, die Bühne.
tgt_text.49: )Feiern den Auszug darf ich, den freudigen, zeichenbeglückten, Unserer Herrn — denn es blieb mir der Born des Gesang Das Gottvertrau'n, Jung im alternden Herzen — Wie einst den zwiethronigen Stolz der Achäer, Hellenischer s Jugend Einige Feldherrn, Fort mit Speer und mit rächendem Arme die thurstigen Aare Sandten gen Troja, — Luftreichs Könige Seereichs Königen, Einer im schwarzen Gesieder, und hinter ihm Der andre weiß, zeigend sich nah bei der Burg, an der rech­ ten Seite;
tgt_text.50: Auf weitschauendem Horste Saßen sie, weideten sie vom Geweide der tragenden Häsin Im letzten Lauf zum Tod erhascht.
tgt_text.53: Das Gute siege!Und der erfahrene Seher, den zwei kampfthurstigen Herrn zu Wendend den Blick—in den Hasenverschlingern erkannt' er Des Zugs Führer;
tgt_text.55: „Wohl wird dereinst Priamos Feste die Beute der Heerfahrt;
tgt_text.56: Alle des Schlosses, Alle des Volkes gesammelte Schätze, sie wird mit Gewalt einst Rauben die Moira;
tgt_text.57: Daß nur irgend ein Grollen der Götter nicht Treffe die Jlionsgeißel, die prunkende, Mit bösem Blick.
tgt_text.58: Wahrlich die lautere Artemis zürnet den gier'gen Flügelhunden des Vaters, Weil mit der Frucht sie die arme, bevor sie geboren, zerfleischten;
tgt_text.59: Sie haßt der Adler arges Mahl."
tgt_text.63: „Ob auch, o Holde, sorglich so Des wilden Leu'n blindgeborne Jungen, Alles heidegewohnten Wildes Milchlüsterne Brut du schirmest, — Mach' von der Wahrschau wahr das Erfreuliche, Wahrschau zur Rechten wohl, aber doch recht nicht ganz.
tgt_text.64: Dem Helfer will ich, dem Paian rufen, Daß du den Danaern nimmer ermüdender widriger Winde Fahrthemmung sendest, Rüstend ein anderes Opfer, gesetzlos, mahllos, ruchlos, Anfang bittersten Hasses daheim, manntrotzenden Grolls;
tgt_text.65: denn eS harret Sein ja die arge, empörte Tückische Herrin im HauS, Harrt kindesgedenke Rachgier!"
tgt_text.66: Also geweissagt wurde von Kalchas zu freudigstem Glücke Böses aus fahrtvordeutendem Aar dem Hause der Fürsten.
tgt_text.67: Diesem ein gleiches Ailinon, Ailinon ruft!
tgt_text.69: Das Gute siege!Zeus, wer Zeus auch immer möge sein, ist er dieses Na­ mens froh, Will ich gern- ihn nennen so;
tgt_text.70: Ihm vergleichen kann ich nichts, wenn ich alles auch erwäg', Außer ihm selbst — so des Denkens vergebliche Qualen
tgt_text.71: Ich in Wahrheit bannen will!So, wer ehedem gewaltig war, allbewehrten Trotzes hehr, — Tiefgestürzt, nicht gilt er mehr;
tgt_text.72: Der darauf erstand, dem Allsieger unterlag auch der;
tgt_text.73: Aber den Zeus im Gesänge des Sieges zu preisen, Alles Denkens Frieden ist's!
tgt_text.74: Ihn der uns zum ernsten Nachsinnen leitet, uns in Leid Lernen läßt zu seiner Zeit.
tgt_text.75: Drum scheucht, wach im Herzen, fort den Schlaf Kummer leideingedenk, und es keimt Wider Willen weiser Sinn.
tgt_text.76: Wohl heißt streng und schonungslos der ew'gen, Hochgethronten Götter Gunst!Also jenes Griechenzugs ältrer Führer, sorgenvoll, Seinem Seher sonder Groll, Mannhaft böser Fügung fügend sich, Als in fahrtloser Rast, knapper Kost, Schwierig schon, das Griechenheer An dem Aulisstrand gelagert rückwärts Chalkis Brandung strömen sah.
tgt_text.77: Vom Strymon her wehten schlimme Winde Ruhloser Ruh', hafenlosen Treibens, Des Zug's Verzug, Für Tau und Kiel immer neu Gefährde;
tgt_text.78: In trostlos langer Säumniß welkend Schwand schon dahin Hellas blühnde Jugend;
tgt_text.79: — Und als ein Mittel nun Aerger den Fürsten selbst als ärgsten Verzug der Seher Artemis Zorn deutend erfand, und sie den Stab tief in den Sand Stießen und selbst Thränen sie nicht hemmten, des Atreus Söhne,Da also sprach dieses Wort der Aeltre:
tgt_text.80: „Es lastet schwer, wag' ich, nicht zu folgen, — Und schwer, mein Kind Dem Tod zu weihn, meines HauseS Liebling, Am Altar diese Hand zu tauchen, Die Vaterhand, in der Tochter Opferblut!
tgt_text.82: Soll ich, ein Flüchtling, heimziehn, Bündniß und Macht verscherzend?
tgt_text.83: Wenn sie das windstillende Sühnopfer, das jungfräuliche Blut Fordern mit Dräun— dräuender wehrt's Themis;
tgt_text.85: "Als er dem Joch grauser Noth sich beugte, — Die Brust ihm aufbrandend ungeheuren Entschlusses — gottlos, heillos — da Ergriff es ihn, Alles nun zu wagen.
tgt_text.86: So frevelkühn macht ein erstes, arges Verirren, sinneverstört, Jammers Urquell!
tgt_text.87: Er trug's nun, die Hand zu legen
tgt_text.88: An das eigne Kind, — zu Frommen Weibrächender Meerfahrt, — Opfer der Schiffesweihe!
tgt_text.89: Ihr Bitten nicht, nicht ihr Vaterrufen, Nicht ihre jungfräulich süße Jugend Erbarmte der Feldherrn wilden Muth.
tgt_text.90: Der Vater sprach sein Gebet, gebot dann Dem Opferknecht, einer Ziege gleich sie Zum Altar niederzuziehn, tuchumfaltet, Sie vorbeugend, festen Muthes — Und den schönen Mund zu hüten, Daß nicht er zum Fluchschrei Wider das Haus sich öffne;
tgt_text.92: Und als hinab floß der Strom von Purpur, Da warf den Pfeil ihres Blicks sie Auf jeden ihrer Opfrer flehend, — Gleich einem Bild schön und stumm, als wollte sie Anreden, die sie sonst daheim oft genug Begrüßt im mahlreichen Saal des Vaters, Wenn mädchenhaft frommen Mund's Preis und Heil Sie gesungen bei des Mahls Spendeschluß, Im Paian feiernd den lieben Vater!Was drauf geschah, sah ich nicht, sag' ich nicht.
tgt_text.93: Doch unerfüllt bleibet Kalchas Kunst nicht!
tgt_text.94: Wohl wäget dem, welcher leidet, Zu lernen Dike zu.
tgt_text.95: Die Zukunft, — Wohin sie treibt, nicht zu wissen wünsch' ich eS — Dem wär' voraus trauern gleich;
tgt_text.96: Denn kommen hell, gleich dem Morgen, wird sie!
tgt_text.97: O gäb' es dann fort und fort frohes Heil, Wie eS dort des Apialand's Burg ersehnt, Die einsam jetzt nur der Herrin Hand schirmt.
tgt_text.98: (Slytaimnestra mit Gefolge ist von dem Umgang durch die Stadt zurück- gekehrt.)
tgt_text.99: Ich nah' in Ehrfurcht deiner Hoheit, Königin.
tgt_text.100: Denn so zu ehren ziemet sich's des Königes Gemahlin, wenn verwaist der Thron ist seines Herrn.
tgt_text.101: Doch ob du Glaubenswerthes hörtest, oder nicht, Daß du in botschaftsfroher Hoffnung opfertest, Das gern erführ' ich;
tgt_text.102: schweigst du, so bescheid' ich mich.Mit froher Kunde, wie's im Sprüchwort heißet, mag Das Morgenroth uns kommen von der Mutter Nacht!
tgt_text.103: Ja, Freude höret über alle Hoffnung groß:
tgt_text.104: Des Priamos Feste hat erobert unser Heer.Was ist?
tgt_text.105: Unglaublich, ist entgangen mir dein Wort!
tgt_text.107: Sprach ich nun es klar?Es ergreift mich Freude;
tgt_text.108: Thränen ruft sie mir hervor!Daß du es wohl meinst, zeigt dein Aug' mir unverstellt.Und was verbürgt dir's? hast du Zeugniß und Beweis?Gewiß, wie sonst denn?
tgt_text.109: wenn ein Gott mich nicht betrog.Du ehrst vielleicht ein überredend Traumgesicht?Nie würd' ich Glauben schlafestrunknem Sinne leihn.So macht ein schnellbeschwingt Gerücht dich wohl so froh?Als wär' ich ein kindisch Mädchen, so verhöhnst du mich.
tgt_text.110: Seit welcher Zeit ist's, daß die Stadt vernichtet ward?
tgt_text.111: Seit dieser Nacht ist's, welche diesen Tag gebar.
tgt_text.112: Doch welcher Bote mochte sich so schleunig nahn?Hephaistos, der vom Jda hellen Strahl gesandt!
tgt_text.113: Denn her geschickt hat in der Feuer Wechselpost Ein Brand den andern, Jda selbst zum Hermesfels In Lemnos.
tgt_text.114: Von der Insel her zum dritten nahm Den breiten Lichtstrahl auf des Zeus Athosgebirg, Wo schnell des Bergwalds Fichtenstoß aufloderte.
tgt_text.115: Hochleuchtend, daß der Wandrerin Flamme mächt'ger Schein Weithin der Meerfluth Rücken überflog, ein Brand Der Freude, flammte strahlend, einer Sonne gleich, Zur Warte des Makistos hin des Lichts Bericht.
tgt_text.116: Die schürte weiter, säumig nicht, noch unbedacht Vom Schlaf bewältigt, ihren Botentheil hinaus.
tgt_text.117: Und wieder fernhin eilend gen Euripos Fluth Rief auf der Strahl die Wächter auf Messapios.
tgt_text.118: Die dann entbrannten und entsandten neuen Schein, Entzündend ihren Haufen dürren Heidekrauts.
tgt_text.119: Die rüst'ge Flamme, nicht ermüdet noch geschwächt, Sie eilte weithin über Asopos Ebene, Gleich Hellem Mondlicht, gen Kithairons Felsenstirn, Und weckte schnell der Flammenboten Wechsel auf.
tgt_text.120: Fernhin erkennbar neues Feuer schürte dort Die Wache;
tgt_text.121: aufschlug's höher hier denn irgendwo Und warf den Glanz weit über den Gorgopis See.
tgt_text.122: Auf Aigiplanktos Scheitel treffend trieb es an, Des Fanales Lichtbahn nicht zu stören;
tgt_text.124: Sie sandten gluthanschürend wolkenglüh'nden Scheins Den mächt'gen Schweif der Flamme, daß er fernhinauS Die weite Spiegelfläche des Saronischen Meerbusens leuchtend überstrahlte, bis er kam Zu Arachnaions Gipfel nah bei unsrer Stadt.
tgt_text.125: Von dort ergoß dies Feuer sich in dieses Schloß Der Atriden, ächter Enkel der Jdäischen Gluth.
tgt_text.126: So war die Ordnung dieses Fackellaufs bestimmt, Und so, mit Flamme Flamme wechselnd, schnell erfüllt;
tgt_text.127: Im Flammenlauf die erst' und letzte hat den Preis.
tgt_text.128: Ein solches Zeugniß, solches Zeichen nenn' ich dir Aus Troja mir voraus von meinem Mann gesandt.Die Götter, Herrin, preisen will ich sie sogleich;
tgt_text.129: Doch anzuhören, anzustaunen jenes Wort Von Neuem, möcht' ich, daß von Neuem du es sprächst.'s ist Jlion der Griechen Beute diesen Tag!
tgt_text.130: Ich glaub', ein mißgemischt Geschrei durchhallt die Stadt.
tgt_text.131: Gießt Oel und Essig du in Einen Krug, so siehst Du sie geschieden fort und fort, einander fremd;
tgt_text.132: So wird der Sieger, so der Besiegten Rufen dort Geschieden, so zwiefachen Schicksals Zeichen sein.
tgt_text.133: Die Einen, hingesunken bei den Leichen der Erschlagnen Männer, der Geschwister, und das Kind Beim greisen Vater, sie beklagen nimmer mehr Mit freier Kehle dies Geschick der Theuersten;
tgt_text.134: Die Andern, nachtdurchirrend hungermatte Gier Hat sie zum Imbiß, wie und wo die Stadt ihn beut, Verwildert, reihlos Reih und Glied, umher zerstreut, Wie jeder je das Loos des Glückes sich gewann;
tgt_text.135: In Troja Hausen jetzt sie in den eroberten Pallästen, für des freien Feldes Lagerplatz Und kalten Thau ein guter Tausch;
tgt_text.137: Und ohne Wache schlafen sie die ganze Nacht.
tgt_text.138: Und ehren jetzt sie jenes Landes, jener Stadt, Der Besiegten Götter und der Götter Tempel, dann Vielleicht erliegt der Sieger nicht dem eignen Sieg.
tgt_text.139: Nur komme Gier nicht über unser Heer, besiegt Vom Reiz der Beute, anzutasten Heil'ges auch;
tgt_text.140: Gefährdet wäre sonst der vielen Müh' Gewinn;
tgt_text.141: Es braucht zur Heimkehr noch zurück der zweiten Fahrt, Bevor des Seezugs Doppelbahn vollendet ist.
tgt_text.142: Ja käm' den Göttern unversündigt heim das Heer, Wach könnte dennoch werden der Erschlagnen Blut, Geschäh' hinfort auch keine neue Frevelthat.
tgt_text.143: Von mir, von einem Weibe, habe das gehört;
tgt_text.144: Das Gute siege, sonder Schwanken voll und klar.Du sprachst, o Herrin, würdig eines Würdigen;
tgt_text.145: Ach aber will den Göttern, da mich überzeugt Dein früher Zeugniß, singen meinen frohen Dank;
tgt_text.146: Denn hoher Lohn gewähret ward für viele Müh! (Alytaimnestra ab.)(Während sich der Chor, die Thymele umwandelnd, zum Wechselgesang ordnet.)
tgt_text.147: Allherrschender Zeus! und du freundliche Nacht, Du Spenderin schmückendsten Ruhmes, Die du fest anzogst um Jlions Burg Dein fangendes Garn, Und keiner entkam, nicht klein, noch groß, Dem gewaltigen Netze der Dienstbarkeit, Dem Alles erfassenden Unheil!
tgt_text.148: Ja Preis dir, Zeus, du des GastrechtS Hort, Der du das zu erfüllen an Priamos Sohn Längst hieltest den Bogen der Rache gespannt, Das weder zu früh, noch ins blaue Gewölk
tgt_text.149: Ein eitel Geschoß hinschwirrte!Wie Zeus trifft, mag man hier erkennen!
tgt_text.150: Und sehn kann, wer den Spuren nachgeht:
tgt_text.152: Irgend wer leugnet, daß die Götter Hinzusehn würdigen, Wenn auch ein Mensch Heiligstes Mit Füßen tritt;
tgt_text.154: Bezeugt ist hier ihr Zorn Dem scheulos Gierigen Voll Wagmuth wilder, denn gerecht war, Voll Hochmuth überstolzen Glückes, Im Uebermaaß schuldig!
tgt_text.155: Sei mein Geschick niedrig, sei der Armuth Reines Gewissen g'nug mir!
tgt_text.156: Schutz nicht bietet der Reichthum Dem, der Glückes gesättigt Frech zertrat der Gerechtigkeit Altar, gegen Vernichtung!
tgt_text.157: Es drängt ihn emsig Ueberreden, Wahnrathend Schmeichelkind des Unheils;
tgt_text.158: 's ist Rettung allvergeblich! - Nie verglimmt, hell in Flammen bricht Grausig hell durch die Schuld!
tgt_text.159: Gleich schlechter Goldmünze nützt Gebrauch und Zeit prüfend ab Den Goldschein falsch gemünzt!
tgt_text.160: ^ Denn nachlief knabenhaft Bethört der schnellbeschwingtem Vogel, Der Heimath schlimmsten Schimpfes Anfang!
tgt_text.161: Sein Jammern hört keiner Der Götter an;
tgt_text.162: sieht er nah den Strand schon, Faßt ihn die Fluth, er sinket!
tgt_text.163: Also Paris, der damals Gast im Haus der Atriden Frech den gastlichen Tisch entweiht, der die Gattin entführt hat.Dem Volk daheim ließ sie kriegsrüst'gen Lärm Und Schildesklang, Speergedräng, Schiffsgeschrei am Strande, Nahm Jlions Verderben mit als Brautgeschenk.
tgt_text.164: So floh sie durch die Pforte dahin, Verwegnes wagend.
tgt_text.165: Und es seufzten laut, Wehklagten laut ihres Hauses Seher:
tgt_text.166: O Haus! o Haus! wehe, weh dir Fürstenstamm!
tgt_text.169: Dort er beschimpft, sonder Zorn, sonder Vorwurf, schweigend, Süßträumend, die er verlor, zu schauen, Er wähnt voll Sehnsucht, der Meerflücht'gen Geist Walte noch wie sonst im Haus;
tgt_text.170: Schöngemeißelter Bilder Anmuth ist ihm zuwider, Ihres Auges Verlorne Lust aller Liebe Verlust ihm!Und traumverwebt, trauerreich umschweben Gestalten ihn, seines Grams wunderholdes Trugspiel.
tgt_text.171: So trughaft, wenn du Liebstes wähnst zu schaun, So flüchtig deinen Händen, entflohn Verfliegt, verschwindet dir mit leisem Flügel Dein Traumgesicht weit in Schlafes Weiten.
tgt_text.172: Also der Gram an des Fürstenhauses Heerd;
tgt_text.173: Schon der so groß, — aber andrer größer noch.
tgt_text.174: Denn wer im Heer mit hinaus zog aus Hellas' Landen, Endloses Grämen weilet daheim In seinem Haus;
tgt_text.175: nagend still, Tag und Nacht Schwellt die Herzen Bitterkeit;
tgt_text.176: Denn wen jeder dahin gab, Weiß er;
tgt_text.177: aber zurückkehrt Statt des Mannes in jeglich Haus sein Gewaffen und Asche.
tgt_text.178: Ares der Leichname Goldwechsler ist's, Im Kampf des Speers blut'ger Todeswäger, Von Troja heim sendet er den Lieben
tgt_text.179: Ein kleines trübsel'ges Ueberbleibsel, An Mannes Statt mit Staub gefüllt schönverzierten Aschen­ krug!
tgt_text.180: Drum jammern sie, hochpreisend den als des Kampfes kun­ digsten, Und jenen, daß er herrlich fiel, kämpfend um fremden Mannes Weib fiel!
tgt_text.181: So im Stillen wird gemurrt, Und es beschleicht des Kampfes Urheber des Grames Vorwurf.
tgt_text.182: Aber'wer da gefallen, Nun Einlieger des Troerlands, Feindeserde bedeckt ihn.Es lastet schwer Volkes Stimme grollvergällt, Und dereinst rächt sich volkentpreßter Fluch.
tgt_text.183: Zu hören bangt meine Sorg' ein Ende Endloser Nacht!
tgt_text.184: Unerspäht den Göttern Bleibt nimmermehr, wer Blut vergoß;
tgt_text.185: und der Erinnyen schwarze Schaar Quält den, der glücklich wider Recht ist, einst mit glück­ verdorrter Fristung Des Lebens todt;
tgt_text.186: dem so dahinwelkenden bleibet keine Ret­ tung.
tgt_text.187: Und des Ruhmes Uebermaaß Lastet ja schwer;
tgt_text.188: denn seinen Blitz schleudert des Donn­ rers Neidblick!
tgt_text.189: Mein mag mäßiges Glück sein, Weder Städtezertrümmrer Möcht'ich sein, noch von Feindeshand essen das Brod der Knechtschaft.Das botenfrohe Feuer ließ Durch unsere Stadt schnell Gerücht Eilen;
tgt_text.190: aber ob es wahr, wer weiß es?
tgt_text.191: Oder ist es gottgesandter Wahn?Wer ist so kindergläubig, so berückten Sinns, An dieses Scheins neuer Kunde sein Gemüth Erst zu wärmen, dann enttäuscht bittren Tausches siech zu sein?
tgt_text.192: Für Weibes Witz paßt es, eh' sie offenbar, Schon zu preisen Glückes Gunst!Leichtgläubig zu leicht verbreitet sich Frauengeschwätz Wie Windeswehn;
tgt_text.193: doch windverweht Versinkt zu Nichts weiberausposaunt Gerücht!Bald offenbart sich's, ob der Botensackellauf, Die Wachtfanale und die Feuerwehcselpost, Wahrhaftig waren, oder ob nach Traumes Art Des frohen Lichtes Kommen mir den Sinn getäuscht, Ich seh' den Herold vom Gestade schon sich nah'n, Das Haupt vom Oelzweig überschattet;
tgt_text.195: Des KotheS Zwillingsbruder auch, der durst'ge Staub, Nicht werde lautlos, nicht von Feuern hochgeschürt In des Berges Waldung ferner Rauch uns Bote sein;
tgt_text.196: Nein klaren Worts bringt uns entweder sein Bericht Mehr Freude — was entgegen dem, vershcweig' ich gern;
tgt_text.197: Mag gut zum schon gewährten Guten sein der Schluß.
tgt_text.198: (Ab.)Wer jenes andre diesem Lande gönnt und wünscht, Der ernte selbst, einst seiner Mißgunst schnöden Wunsch!
tgt_text.199: (Der Herold kommt.)O theurer Heimathboden, mein Argeiisch Land!
tgt_text.200: Mit dieses zehnten Jahres Sonne kehr' ich heim, Zwar mancher Hoffnung ärmer, doch in einer reich:
tgt_text.201: Denn nimmer glaubt' ich, daß in Argos Erde noch Des liebsten Grabes Stätte mir beschieden sei.
tgt_text.202: Nun sei gegrüßt, Land! sei gegrüßt, du Sonnenlicht!
tgt_text.203: Und du des Landes Walter Zeus! du Pythischer Fürst, Mit feindlichem Bogen fürder uns nicht pfeilgewiß, — Entgegen g'nug erschienst du am Skamander uns — Nun wieder sei uns Helfer, sei uns Streitgenoß, Du Fürst Apollon!
tgt_text.204: Euch, ihr kampfbeschirmenden Gottheiten alle, rus ich, meinen Schützer auch Den theuren Herold Hermes, der Herolde Zier!
tgt_text.205: Und ihr Heroen, die uns leitetet, gnädig wollt Das Heer empfangen, das der Lanzen Wuth verschont!
tgt_text.206: Heil dir, du meiner Fürsten Pallast, liebes Haus!
tgt_text.208: Götter ihr im Sonnenlicht, Wenn irgend je, empfanget heitren AugeS jetzt In Würden unsren König nach so langer Zeit;
tgt_text.209: Denn heimgekehrt ist, euch und diesen Allen Licht Nach trüber Nacht zu bringen, Agamemnons Macht!
tgt_text.210: Ihr werdet festlich ihn empfahn, wie's dem gebührt, Der Jlion zerstörte mit des Rächer ZeuS Grabscheit, von der dort umgestürzt der Boden liegt.
tgt_text.211: Vershcwunden sind der Götter Tempel und Altar, Und allvernichtet alles Feldes Saat umher.
tgt_text.212: Der solches Joch anschirrte Priams stolzer Stadt, Der Sohn des Atreus, unser glückgekrönter Held, Er kommt, vor Allen höchster Ehre werth, so viel Jetzt leben.
tgt_text.213: Paris noch die mitgestrafte Stadt Berühmen fürder größrer That denn Buße sich;
tgt_text.214: Denn er, des Raubes, der Entführung schuldig, fand Sich keinen Retter;
tgt_text.215: sein zum Tod gezeitigter Ureingeborner Fürstenstamm, er riß ihn aus!
tgt_text.216: So ward der Priamiden Doppelschuld gebüßt!Achäerherold, Freude dir! sei froh begrüßt!Ja Freude;
tgt_text.219: Dich hat Verlangen nach der Heimath wohl gequält?So daß die Freude Thränen meinem Aug' entlockt!
tgt_text.220: Gekranket habt auch ihr an diesem süßen Weh?Auch ihr? belehrt erst werd' ich deines Wortes Herr!Getrauert voll Verlangen nach Verlangenden?Hat heim das Land sein heim sich sehnend Heer gesehnt
tgt_text.221: ?So daß ich oftmals tief geseufzt in trübem Sinn!Längst heißt mir Schweigen alles Grames einz'ger Arzt!
tgt_text.222: Der Fürsten Fernsein, machte dich's vor wem besorgt?Ich nehme dein „jetzt stürb' ich gern" auch an für mich.Ja schön vollbracht ist's! freilich in so langer Zeit, Fügt, mag man sagen, günstig wohl sich dies und das, Doch andres wieder übel.
tgt_text.223: Doch, wer außer Gott Ist sonder Leiden fort und fort sein Lebelang?
tgt_text.224: Wollt' unsre Mühsal ich erzählen, — auf der Fahrt, Des Schlafs wenig' und auf hartem Lager — denn
tgt_text.225: Die nackte Schiffsbank unterm Deck war unser Bett — Und Tages keine Stunde frei von Dienst und Müh';
tgt_text.226: Gar auf dem Festland kam dazu noch neue Noth;
tgt_text.227: Vom Himmel Regen und vom Wiesengrund herauf Durchnäßte Thau uns;
tgt_text.228: nimmer trocken wurde man, So daß mit Schwären sich die kranke Haut bezog.
tgt_text.229: Spräch' ich vom Winter, jenem Vogeltödter, gar, Wie unerträglich den des Jda Schnee gebracht, Gar von der Hitze, wenn um Mittagszeit die See In wellenlos windstiller Ruh sich legend schlief — Wozu es klagen?
tgt_text.230: 's ist vorüber alle Müh, Vorüber nun auch denen, die gefallen sind, So daß sie nimmer wieder aufzustehn verlangt.
tgt_text.231: Was soll ich euch herzählen die Gebliebnen, und Mich, der ich lebe, kränken um ihr traurig Loos?
tgt_text.233: Denn uns, die übrig noch wir sind vom Griechenheer, Siegt doch der Vortheil, und das Leid, nicht wiegt's ihn auf.
tgt_text.234: Wer heimgeflogen über Land und über Meer, Darf so sich rühmen vor der Sonne heil'gem Licht:
tgt_text.235: „Erobrer Troja's, haben wir, der Danaer Heer, „Geweiht den Göttern unsre Beute, aufgehängt „In allen Tempeln Griechenlands den theuren Schmuck!"
tgt_text.236: Die solches hören, preisen müssen sie das Volk Und seine Feldherrn;
tgt_text.237: hoch gelobt sei aber auch Zeus Gnade, die's vollbrachte!
tgt_text.241: Von deinem Wort bekenn' ich gern mich überzeugt;
tgt_text.242: Zum steten Lernen bleibet auch das Alter jung.
tgt_text.243: Dies Haus und Klytaimnestra mögen freilich drum Vor Allen froh sein;
tgt_text.244: aber mit beglückt's auch mich.Laut aufgejauchzet hab' ich längst in Heller Lust, Als meines Feuers erster nächt'ger Bote kam, Troja's Erob'rung und Zerstörung meldend uns.
tgt_text.246: „Solchem Feuershcein Vertrauend glaubst du, Jlion sei nun zerstört?
tgt_text.247: Doch Weiberart ist's, außer sich gar bald zu sein!"
tgt_text.248: Nach solcher Red' erschien ich als ein thöricht Weib;
tgt_text.249: Jedennoh copfern ließ ich und den Jubelruf Erhuben gellend Weiber, andre anderswo, In der Stadt umher froh lärmend, in der Götter Sitz Weihrauchgesättigt duft'ges Feuer sänftigend.
tgt_text.250: Und nun was braucht's noch, daß du mir das Weitre sagst?
tgt_text.251: Die ganze Kunde hör' ich bald vom Fürsten selbst;
tgt_text.252: Drum eil' ich meinen erlauchten Herrn aufs Herrlichste
tgt_text.253: Bei seiner Ankunft hier zu empfahn.
tgt_text.254: Was gab' es auch Für eine Gattin süßeres, als den Tag zu schaun, Wo ihrem Mann, der glücklich heimkehrt aus dem Feld, Das Thor sie aufthut!
tgt_text.256: Zu kommen mög' er eilen, vielersehnt der Stadt;
tgt_text.257: Sein treues Weib im Hause sind' er heimgekehrt Wie er's verlassen, als des Hauses Wächterin, Ihm edlen Sinnes, allen Bösgesinnten feind, In allem Andern noch sich gleich, von ihrer Hand Kein Siegel drinnen während all der Zeit verletzt, Noch weiß von Wollust, von verbotner Heimlichkeit
tgt_text.258: Mit fremdem Manne mehr ich denn vom Bad des Stahls!
tgt_text.259: Ein solcher Selbstruhm, ganz der Wahrheit nur gemäß, Ist tadellos zu sprechen für ein treues Weib! (Klytaimnestra ab.
tgt_text.261: Sie sagt es selbst dir, und du hörst es von ihr selbst, Vom besten Dollmetsch, durch ihr eignes klares Wort!
tgt_text.262: Doch sag' mir, Herold, ist Menelaos auch mit euch Heimwärts gesegelt, ist er wohlbehalten auch Zurückgekommen mit des Landes liebem Heer?Nicht ist eS möglich, daß ich frohe Kunde dir, Der du dich lange könntest freun, erheuchele!Wie träfst du auch das Wahre, wenn du Frohes sagst?
tgt_text.263: Einmal geschieden, offenbart sich's nur zu bald.Der Fürst, er ist vershcollen im Hellenenheer, Er selbst und seine Schiffe.
tgt_text.265: Und war er von Troja abgesegelt ohne euch?
tgt_text.266: Entriß ein Sturm, heimsuchend Alle, ihn dem Heer?Recht trafst du wie ein wackrer Bogenschütz das Ziel;
tgt_text.267: Du sprachst ein langes Leiden aus mit kurzem Wort!Ob er selbst noch lebe, ob er umgekommen sei, Kam's durch Berichte fremder Schiffer nicht umher?Wohl keiner weiß es, der es nacherzählen kann, Als, der der Erde Leben nähret, Helios!Wie aber, sag' uns, ist den Schiffern jener Sturm Gekommen und vollendet durch der Götter Zorn?Mit böser Botschaft sollte man den frohen Tag Niemals entweihen;
tgt_text.269: Bringt aber heim ein Bote der gefallenen Heerschaaren unaussprechlich Leid, mit trüber Stirn Die Wunden heim, die eine des gesammten Volks, Und andere viele, weil aus vielem Haus den Mann Hinausgepeitschet Ares Doppelgeißel hat, — Zweischneidiges Unheil, blut'ge Gramverschwisterung — Ja wem ein solcher Jammer aufgebürdet ist, Den soll man nennen der Erinnyen Ehrenhold;
tgt_text.270: Doch „Freudenbote glücklich überstandner Noth" Den, welcher heimkehrt froh zur frohen Vaterstadt.
tgt_text.271: Wie misch' ich Liebes Bösem bei, wenn ich vom Sturm, Den Götter uns Achäern zürnten, sprechen soll?
tgt_text.272: Denn da vershcwur sich, was sich sonst das feindlichste, Meerfluth und Feuer, sie bewährten ihren Bund Vernichtend der Argeier unglückselges Heer.
tgt_text.273: Es erhob zur Nachtzeit sich der empörten Fluthen Sturz, Aneinander jagte die Schiffe wilder Thrakischer Orkan;
tgt_text.274: sie selbst, im Ungestüm des Schlossensturms, Des Typhoischen Wetters, wild vom Horn des Kiels zerfleischt, Vershcwanden spurlos unter des Treibers Wirbelsturz.
tgt_text.275: Als dann das Frühlicht tagend endlich wieder schien, Da sahn wir rings des stillen Meeres Spiegel blühn Von Griechenleichen, von zerschellter Schiffe Wrack.
tgt_text.276: Uns aber hat und unser unversehrtes Schiff Entwendet, glaub ich, oder bittend frei gemacht Ein Gott, — ein Mensch nicht, — der das Fahrzeug uns gelenkt.
tgt_text.277: Dann saß am Steuer gnädig Tyche Retterin, Daß nicht die Sturzfluth hohler See uns kentern ließ, Noch unter Land am Felsenriff wir scheiterten.
tgt_text.278: Also dem Hades'des empörten Meers entflohn, Mißtrauten unsrem Glück wir auch am heitren Tag, Und ließen weiden unsren Gram das neue Leid Des mühbeladnen, jammervoll zerstäubten Heers.
tgt_text.279: Und freut von jenen einer noch des Athems sich, So spricht von uns er als von Todten;
tgt_text.281: Auch wir ja meinen, ihnen sei es so geschehn.
tgt_text.282: O möcht' es gut sich wenden! wenn vor Allem nur, Zuerst Menelas nur einen sichren Port erreicht!
tgt_text.283: Denn wenn ein Lichtblick irgend noch des Helios Ihn leben sieht und weben durch Zeus ew'gen Rath, Der sein Geschlecht doch nimmermehr vertilgen will, So bleibet Hoffnung, daß er einst noch wiederkehrt.
tgt_text.284: So viel du hörtest, wisse, Wahrheit hörtest du! (Herold ab.
tgt_text.286: Wer erfand den Namen einst, Namen allbedeutungsvoll — Wenn nicht Einer, den wir nicht sehn, vorausschauend, was die Schickung bringt, Zielgewiß die Zunge lenkt — Helena deutungsvoll die vielstreitige, speererrungne nennend?
tgt_text.287: Hehlenacht, Hehlenoth, Hehluntergang, so zog sie aus des Gemahls Teppichumhängtem Lager fort, fahrend mit segelbläh'ndem Westwind;
tgt_text.288: Und des Kiels fluthenverwehter Fährte nach Jagten mit Schild und Speer die Jäger, Fern gen Simois Uferland steuernd, dem laubumgrünten, Zu dem erbittertsten Blutkampf.Rechte Trauertraue war's, Die den Troern Götterzorn Endesinnend hat gesandt, ob des Gasttisches arge Schmach dereinst, Ob des Heerdbeschirmers Schmach Buße vom Freudenfest, vom brautfeiernden Hymnus einzu­ fordern, Von dem Hochzeitlied, das die Schwäger zu froh sangen daheim.
tgt_text.289: Doch es verlernte solchen Sang bald die ergraute Priamsfeste;
tgt_text.290: Und in Gramliedern beseufzend ihre Noth Schrie sie, verfluchte sie Paris Unthat, Eh' noch als sie das ganze gramvolle Geschick des Volkes sah In dem entsetzlichen Blutbad!Auf zog also ein Mann einst Ein Löwenjunges;
tgt_text.291: dem Lamm als Milchbruder legt' er's an's Euter;
tgt_text.292: Freilich erschien's in der Kindheit Zahm mit den Kindern zu spielen, Recht ein Verzug der Alten, Ruhete oft in ihrem Arm, Einem gehegten Knäbchen gleich, Lüstern blickend zur Hand herauf, an sich schmiegend vor Hunger.Gereift aber enthüllt rasch Die Art er, wie sie ihm angeerbt:
