tgt_text.5329: Vielleicht auf Anlaß des Perserkönigs, der einen seiner Großen nach Sparta gesandt hatte, einen Einfall nach Attika zu veranlassen, um die Attische Macht aus Aegypten zu entfernen.
tgt_text.5330: Nicht ganz so viel wagten die Spartaner;
tgt_text.5331: es schien genug, vorerst jenseits des Jsthmos die Waffen wieder gezeigt und die oligarchischen Staaten dort, namentlich The­ ben, ermuthigt zu haben.
tgt_text.5332: Nachdem sie die Phokier bewäl­ tigt, wollten sie heimziehen;
tgt_text.5333: eine Attische Flotte sperrte ihnen den Weg über den Korinthischen Meerbusen, Megara den Weg über den Jsthmos.
tgt_text.5334: So gaben sie die Heimkehr auf, um so lieber, da bereits sich größere Aussichten eröff­ neten.
tgt_text.5335: Die Oligarchen Athens hatten sich insgeheim an sie gewandt in der Hoffnung, mit ihrer Hülfe die Demo­ kratie zu stürzen.Für Athen die schwerste Gefahr;
tgt_text.5336: eS war unmöglich, das Spartanerheer in Böotien zu dulden;
tgt_text.5337: es mußte ein ent­ scheidender Schlag gewagt werden, wie schwer auch bei der schon so hoch gespannten Kriegslast des Staates die Auf­ stellung eines neuen Heeres sein mochte.Mit dem Frühling 458, bald nach Aufführung der Ore­ steia, rückte das Attische Heer, von Argos und Thessalien her verstärkt, gegen den Feind.
tgt_text.5338: Kimon kam in's Lager, erbot sich, um den allgemein gegen ihn und seine Freunde erhobe­ nen Verdacht zu beschämen, als Hoplit in den Reihen seiner Phyle mitzukämpfen;
tgt_text.5339: zurückgewiesen, beschwor er die Männer seiner Parthei, tapfer kämpfend zu zeigen, daß sie vor Allem Athener seien.
tgt_text.5340: Ihrer hundert fielen in der blutigen Schlacht von Tanagra;
tgt_text.5341: durch den Verrath der Thessalischen Ritter verloren die Athener den Sieg.
tgt_text.5342: Aber auch die Spartaner hatten schweren Verlust;
tgt_text.5343: ihre Hoffnung auf eine Schild­ erhebung der Attischen Oligarchen war vereitelt;
tgt_text.5344: nach Ab­ schluß eines Waffenstillstandes kehrten sie über den JfthmuS heim.Es ist nicht nöthig, die weiteren heldenmütigen An­ strengungen der Athener, ihre Siege über Theben, die Ero­ berung Tanagra's, Boiotiens, des Phokier- und LokrierlandeS bis Thessalien hinein, zu berichten.
tgt_text.5345: Möglich, daß endlich beim Beginn des Feldzuges von Tanagra auf Kimons Rath der Areiopag den weiteren Widerstand gegen die Reform aufgab.
tgt_text.5346: Es war der erste Schritt zur inneren Versöhnung;
tgt_text.5347: der zweite war, daß Kimon auf PerikleS Antrag, bevor die Hälfte seiner Exiljahre verflossen war, zurückberufen wurde.
tgt_text.5348: Die Kriege währten noch über diese Zeit hinaus;
tgt_text.5349: so unge­ heure Opfer sie forderten, Athen bestand sie.Inmitten dieser Bewegungen und Verhältnisse hat Ai­ schyloS seine OresteStrilogie gedichtet.
tgt_text.5350: Fast ein Sieb­ ziger, steht er, der Eupatride, unter dem jüngeren Ge­ schlecht;
tgt_text.5351: er hat die schlimmsten Jahre der Tyrannis, die Umwälzungen der Kleisthenischen Zeit mit durchge­ lebt, in den drei herrlichsten Schlachten für die Freiheit und den heimathlichen Ruhm gekämpft;
tgt_text.5352: an den schönsten Festen des Attischen Staates hat er Tugend und Weisheit und Mäßigung gelehrt und im heiligen Priesterthum des Gesanges des Volkes Gesinnung geläutert und gehoben;
tgt_text.5353: er weiß, wie hoch er geehrt ist, wie mächtig sein Wort, wie erschütternd seine Kunst zu wirken vermag.
tgt_text.5354: Noch einmal will er auftreten, seine Kunst und seinen Ruhm verwenden zum Schutz des vaterländischen Wohles, das er gefährdet sieht;
tgt_text.5355: ihm weiht er das letzte, das herrlichste Werk seiner riesigen Kunst.So dichtet er den Mythos von Orestes' des Muttermör­ ders Flucht nach Athen, von der Stiftung des AreiopagoS durch Pallas Athene, von der Begründung des ernsten Dienstes der Eumeniden, die am Fuße des Aresberges weilen, den Frieden im Lande zu hüten.
tgt_text.5356: Und dieser Friede ist nun durch Ephialtes Mord zerbrochen, der Areiopag, durch Ephial­ tes' Reformen in Frage gestellt, nicht mehr fähig ihn in alter Art zu hüten;
tgt_text.5357: die Erinnyen singen ihren Fesselhymnus zu der Menge umher, in deren Mitte der Mörder weilen mag!
tgt_text.5360: Die blutigen Hände verheimlicht, Da treten wir laut als Zeugen der Schuld Den Erschlagenen auf und erweisen uns dem, Der erschlug, als Rächer der Blutschuld.
tgt_text.5361: Aischylos läßt wohl erkennen, wen er für den Mörder hält (V. 347):
tgt_text.5362: Mannes Hoffahrt, prunke sie droben auch preislichst, Nieder zur Erde hin sinkt sie, verkümmert sie rühmlos.
tgt_text.5363: Hingestürzt – nicht sieht er's in seiner Bethörung;
tgt_text.5364: Also ein irrendes Dunkel umnachtet die Schuld ihn;
tgt_text.5365: Und von dem Schatten, der finster durch sein Geschlecht Hingeht, redet tausendfacher Mund.
tgt_text.5366: Das ist der, welcher „der Leichname Goldwechsler, den Ares, den blutigen Todeswäger" herausgefordert hat, aus dem nun der Fluch derer, die so theure Todte verloren, haf­ tet (Agam. 413);
tgt_text.5367: aber „unerspäht den Göttern bleibt nim­ mermehr, wer Blut vergoß".
tgt_text.5368: Und so singen denn die Rache­ göttinnen (Eumeniden V. 506):
tgt_text.5370: Uebertreter, Trotzes, frech, So reich ihr Schiff voll Gutes wider Recht, Gewaltsam, – ihre Segel senken Werden sie bald, wenn jäher Sturm Faßt die zerschellten Masten.
tgt_text.5371: Sein Hülfeschrein, wenn er gegen Strudels Wuth Ringt, erhöret Niemand;
tgt_text.5372: Es lacht der Gott ob des heißen Eifrers, So ihn, der stets Rath zu wissen sich berühmt, Rathlos zu sehn – aufzutauchen nur, zu schwach!
tgt_text.5373: Zuletzt sammt seinem einstigen Reichthum Strandend am Fels des Rechts versinkt er;
tgt_text.5375: Denn es wird schon zu Tage kommen, wer jenen Mord be­ ging, dann wird er, „stark wie er ist" (V. 335), doch dem Blutgericht auf dem Areiopag verfallen und seinen Lohn finden.
tgt_text.5376: Und furchtbaren Zwiespalt hat jener Mord im Land erweckt;
tgt_text.5377: die Erinnyen des vergossenen Blutes sind wach, Pallas Athene sucht sie zu versöhnen (Eumeniden V. 794):
tgt_text.5378: – So schleudert nicht in unserm Land umher Den blutgewetzten Hader.
tgt_text.5379: Haßverwilderung Jn's Herz der Jugend, Trunkenheit weinloser Wuth;
tgt_text.5380: Noch Trutz entzündend wie in Hahnes Herzen laß In meinen Bürgern Stätte du dem Ares sein Des Bürgerkrieges und des wechselseitigen Grimms;
tgt_text.5381: Nein, außer Landes sei der ganz schon nahe Krieg, Drin edler Wettkampf wird des Heldenruhmes sein, Doch Kampf von Eines Hof's Geflügel mein' ich nicht.
tgt_text.5382: So nahe bevor steht der Kampf von Tanagra, in dem der Dichter nichts weniger wünscht, als daß Eines Hof's Ge­ flügel sich bekämpfen, Attische Oligarchen auf Seiten des Spartanischen Heers stehen, jener Krieg, zu dem auch das Argeier Hülfsheer kommt, dessen „Bundestreuen Speer" (Eumeniden V. 726) Orestes noch in seinem Grabe zu segnen verspricht.
tgt_text.5384: r Mag des Aufruhres Wuth, Leides Nimmersatte Wuth Tosen nie in diesem Land, Nimmer der Staub mit dem Blute der Bürger getränkt, Rachedürstend, Wehcselmordende Blutsühne Heischend, zerreißen die Stadt.
tgt_text.5385: Tausche man Freuden um Freuden, Eins in der Liebe zum Ganzen, Auch im Hassen Eines Sinns;
tgt_text.5386: Das heilt vielen Gram der Sterblichen.
tgt_text.5387: Und Pallas preist „der Peitho Kunst", kraft deren eS ge­ lungen, Daß ich sie, die sich wild mir versagten, erweicht;
tgt_text.5388: aber den Sieg gebracht hat der Zeus Agoraios, der die Macht der politischen Beredsamkeit schirmende (V. 916):
tgt_text.5389: Stets sieget bei uns Wetteifernd Bemühn für das Gute.
tgt_text.5390: So hat Aischylos in seiner Trilogie gleichsam eine Sühnefeier für die auf dem Lande lastende Blutschuld ge­ dichtet, eine Versöhnung zugleich zwischen den wilden Par­ theien, die den Staat zu vernichten drohen, die alle Eines Sinnes sein sollen, um den nahen Feind abzuwehren.
tgt_text.5391: Aber den einzigen wahren Schutz findet er in der Erhaltung des bedrohten Areopag:
tgt_text.5392: „nicht unbeherrshct, nicht gewaltgeknechtet zu sein" ist das Rechte;
tgt_text.5393: „jeglicher Mitte gewähren die Götter den Preis".
tgt_text.5397: Scheu' den Herd stets „des Rechts", Nimmermehr Tritt ihn, Gewinn zu erspähen, mit frevlem Fuß!
tgt_text.5398: Pallas Athene selbst setzt diesen hohen Rath ein, „daß er für alle Zukunft bleibe und bestehe" (Eumeniden V. 643):
tgt_text.5400: An ihn des Volks Ehrfurcht und ihre Schwester Furcht Dem Frevel wehren, beides Nächtens und am Tag, Wenn nicht die Bürger selber neuern mein Gesetz Mit schlechtem Zuguß.
tgt_text.5401: Doch so du den klaren Quell Mit Schlamm verunreinst, labt er nicht den Durst'gen mehr.
tgt_text.5402: Nicht unregiert und nicht gewaltbeherrscht zu sein, Das sei dem Volk, fürsorgend rath' ich's, hoch und werth.
tgt_text.5403: Und nicht entfernt euch alles Furchterweckende;
tgt_text.5404: Denn welcher Mensch bleibt, wenn er nichts mehr scheut, gerecht?
tgt_text.5405: Wenn solcher Ehrfurcht frommen Sinn ihr redlich hegt, Ein rechtes Bollwerk für das Land, ein Heil des Staats, So wie's der Menschen keiner hat, der Skythe nicht Noch auch des Pelops nahe Landschaft, habt dann ihr In diesem Rathe, unbestechlich, ehrenhaft, Dem Frevel zornig, wie ich ihn bestellet hab'
tgt_text.5406: Zur immerwachen Hut im Land, wenn Alles schläft.Man sieht wohl, Aischylos spricht mit der ganzen Weihe seiner Kunst und mit der eindringlichsten Bedeutsamkeit einer feierlich ernsten Situation seine Ansicht aus, die den Neigungen der Menge keineswegs entsprechend ist.
tgt_text.5407: Er ist fest in seinem patriotischen Glauben an die Tüchtigkeit, den guten Sinn, den hohen Beruf seines Vaterlandes;
tgt_text.5408: freilich schon im Jahre vorher ist Kimons Versuch, die eingeleitete Reform durch das Volk selbst rückgängig zu machen, ge­ scheitert;
tgt_text.5409: aber wie anders sind nun auch die Verhältnisse!
tgt_text.5410: Der Zwiespalt zwischen Areiopag und Demos, zwischen der populären und conservativen Richtung ist zum Aeußersten gekommen und droht die Auflösung des Staates;
tgt_text.5411: die ganze Ordnung desselben ist in Frage gestellt;
tgt_text.5412: die alten Formen und Institute erkennt das Volk nicht mehr an, und die neuen extemporisirten haben keine verfassungsmäßige Gültig­ keit;
tgt_text.5413: es erfolgt ein furchtbarer Frevel, gleichsam vor Augen zu stellen, wie heillos dieser interimistische Zustand ist, wie unfähig, den schwersten Verbrechen auch nur auf die Spur zu kommen, geschweige denn ihnen zu wehren (s. Agamem­ non V. 1257 – 1282);
tgt_text.5414: das Kriegsgräuel ras't weiter und weiter, an den Grenzen schon steht der Feind;
tgt_text.5415: es ist die höchste Zeit zur Versöhnung, zur Einigung aller Kraft für die Rettung des Landes.
tgt_text.5416: Aischylos mochte hoffen, mit seinem ernst mahnenden Wort Eindruck auf das Volk von Athen zu machen, es zu Nachgiebigkeit gegen die Parthei, deren Uebergewicht ja gebrochen war, zu Zugeständnissen bewegen zu können, die nun nicht als ein Zeugniß von Schwäche oder Furcht, sondern als ein freies Geschenk und ein Be­ weis edelster Versöhnlichkeit erscheinen mußten;
tgt_text.5417: dann wird man, „einig in der Liebe zum Ganzen, auch im Hassen eines Sinnes", mit neuer Kraft, mit Begeiste­ rung kämpfen und siegen, dann wird Kimon wieder seinem Vaterland angehören, dann der alte, neugeschmückte Areiopag im Sinne der Marathonischen Heldenzeit des Volkes Ruhe sichern, dessen Heftigkeit zügeln, zu allem Würdigsten voran­ schreiten, der Segen der Götter überschwenglich sein – er selbst, der greise Marathonkämpfer, wird den Rest seiner Tage friedlich und vielgeehrt unter dem nachgebornen Ge­ schlecht der Seinen leben, die den edlen Ruhm, den er mit­ erkämpft, treu gewahrt und würdig gemehrt haben!
tgt_text.5419: und mit lautestem Beifall wurde sein herrliches Werk gepriesen;
tgt_text.5420: ihm ward im tragischen Wettkampf der erste Preis zuerkannt.
tgt_text.5421: Doch, was er gewollt, erreichte er nicht;
tgt_text.5422: der Beifall hatte seiner Kunst gegolten;
tgt_text.5423: der höchste Zweck, dem er sie geweiht, war verfehlt;
tgt_text.5424: die einzige Frucht eines Lebens voll Ernst und Arbeit war dies schmerzliche Vergebens;
tgt_text.5425: seiner Kassandra gleich hatte er um­ sonst gewarnt und die Zukunft geschaut:
tgt_text.5426: O dieses Menschenleben – wenn es glücklich ist, Ein Schatten kann es wandeln;
tgt_text.5427: ist's voll Leid, so tilgt Ein feuchter Schwamm dies Bild hinweg – vergessen ist's.
tgt_text.5428: Und mehr denn jenes schmerzt mich dies Vergessensein!
tgt_text.5429: Aischylos mochte sehen, daß seine Zeit vorüber sei.
tgt_text.5430: Einst bei den Jsthmischen Spielen, als ein Kämpfer bewältigt zu Boden stürzte, und dann schweigend, während das Volk jubelte, den Kampfplatz verließ, hatte er zu einem Jüng­ ling, dem blonden Ion von Chios, gesagt:
tgt_text.5431: „Du siehst, o Sohn, wie es mit dem Wettkampf ist;
tgt_text.5432: der Besiegte schweigt und die Zushcauer jauchzen"!
tgt_text.5433: So verließ er nun selbst sein Vaterland und ging nach Gela in Sicilien, dort der Stunde zu harren, wo auch er sagen könnte wie sein Achill:
tgt_text.5434: „die Nachtwache seines Lebens sei vollendet".Es mag eine poetische Erfindung sein, wenn erzählt wird:
tgt_text.5435: er habe einst vor den Mauern der Stadt gesessen, die greisen Glieder zu sonnen, da sei über ihn hin ein Adler geflogen, der die Schildkröte, die er in den Krallen trug, um sie zu zershcmettern, auf die Stirn des Dichters fallen gelassen habe;
tgt_text.5436: so sei das Orakel erfüllt worden, ein himmlisches Geschoß werde ihn todten.
tgt_text.5437: Ehrenvoll bestatteten ihn die Geloer und schrieben auf sein Grab die Inschrift, die er sich selbst gedichtet hatte:
tgt_text.5438: Aischylos ruht allhier, des Euphorion Sohn, der Athener, Welchen der Tod in der kornprangenden Gela bezwang;
tgt_text.5439: Seine, des ruhmvoll Kämpfenden Kraft nennt Marathon's Hain dir, Nennt dir der Meder der dichtlockige, der sie erprobt.Der zum Theil in sehr verderbter Gestalt überlieferte Text der Aischyleischen Tragödien hat in den zwei letzten Jahr­ zehnten und namentlich seit der Ausgabe von G. Hermann durch eine Fülle gelehrter und scharfsinniger Untersuchungen eine vielfach verbesserte Gestalt gewonnen.
tgt_text.5440: Es ist nicht dieses Ortes, die für die Uebersetzung angenommenen Textverände­ rungen zu rechtfertigen;
tgt_text.5441: ebenso wenig würde den Lesern, für welche sie bestimmt ist, damit gedient sein, über die Um­ stellungen einzelner Verse, veränderte Personenvertheilung da und dort und Aehnliches Nachweis zu erhalten.
tgt_text.5442: Anderer Art scheint es zu sein, wenn einzelne Verse be­ seitigt worden sind, welche die Kritiker mit mehr oder we­ niger Uebereinstimmung als unächt erkannt haben.
tgt_text.5443: Von diesen soll hier eine kurze Nachricht gegeben, zugleich von einigen anderen Stellen, über deren Gefüge man zweifeln kann, gesprochen werden.
tgt_text.5444: Im Agamemnon S. 18 ist hinter V. 331 ein stören­ der Vers weggelassen;
tgt_text.5446: Mit theuren Opfern hab' ich solchen Wunsch erkauft.
tgt_text.5447: In den Schlußworten der Scene, die auf S. 55 endet, ist eine für den Sinn und den dramatischen Charakter dieser Stelle bedeutsame Umstellung empfohlen worden.
tgt_text.5448: Sie lautet von V. 1222 an wie folgt:
tgt_text.5449: Nicht Wohlgerüche Syriens rühmst du diesem Schloß.O Freunde!
tgt_text.5450: Nicht beben will ich wie der Vogel vor dem Garn Furchtsam, vergebens.
tgt_text.5451: Was ich sprach, bezeugt es einst, Wenn das Weib an mein, des Weibes Statt erschlagen liegt, An des Mannes Statt der fluchgefreite Mann erliegt;
tgt_text.5452: Zum Gastgeschenke gönnt mir dies, der Sterbenden.Mich jammert, Arme, dein des Wissens traurig Loos.Einmal noch sprechen will ich einen letzten Spruch, Den eignen, meinen.
tgt_text.5453: Bei des Helios letztem Licht, Des Allesschauenden, meines ach so feindlichen Schirmherren, fluch' ich meinen Mördern gleichen Tod!
tgt_text.5454: Weh' dir, erhab'ner König, kriegsgewalt'ger Fürst!)
tgt_text.5455: Weh' mir, der Sclavin, blut'ger Hand ein leichtes Spiel!
tgt_text.5456: Nun geh' ich – und den Schatten sei hinfort geklagt Agamemnons Mord und meiner!
tgt_text.5457: 's ist des Lebens g'nug!O dieses Menschenleben! – wenn es glücklich ist, Ein Schatten kann es wandeln;
tgt_text.5458: ist's voll Leid, so tilgt Ein vollgetränkter Schwamm des Bildes Züge kaum.
tgt_text.5459: Und dies bekümmert tiefer noch als jenes mich!In den Eumeniden S. 133 folgt auf V. 273 eine Zeile, die nicht dem Zusammenhang der Gedanken entspricht:
tgt_text.5460: Es macht die Zeit mitalternd uns von Allem rein.Eben so für unächt wird S. 156 die auf V. 794 fol­ gende Zeile gehalten:
tgt_text.5461: Und um so viel, viel weiser bist du wohl, denn ich.In den Persern S. 186 ist nach V. 28 eine Reihe von zwanzig Versen ausgelassen;
tgt_text.5462: Verse, die nach Inhalt und Form mangelhaft sind, und im Einzelnen dem, was der Dichter im Verlauf der Tragödie von einigen der hier ge­ nannten Führer sagt, widersprechen.
tgt_text.5464: Und der Schlachtroßtummler Artembares auch, Masistres auch, Und Jmaios, der Held, goldbogenbewährt, Und der Rosse Bewält'ger Sosthanes;
tgt_text.5465: Und Andre gesandt hat des schwellenden Nils Fruchtüppiges Thal, Sustskanes, Pegastagon Den Aegyptiersohn;
tgt_text.5466: dann der Fürst Arsames, Der in Memphis Herr, in der heiligen, ist, Und der uralt heiligen Thebä Herr Ariomardoö;
tgt_text.5467: Und vom Bruchland her schiffruderndes Volk, Fahrtkundig, unzählige Menge
tgt_text.5468: Auch des üppigen Stamms in Lydia folgt Viel Volk, dem zumal Sich des Festlands Heer schaarweif anschloß.
tgt_text.5469: Die Arkteus führt und Mitrogathes, Machtfürsten des Reichs;
tgt_text.5470: Auch Sardes sendet, die goldene, viel Kriegsschaaren vertheilt in den Wagen der Schlacht, Die mit Doppelgespann, dreifachem Gespann Furchtbar toddräuend daherziehn.
tgt_text.5471: Aus gleichem Grunde für unächt gilt die S. 197 auf V. 262 folgende Zeile:
tgt_text.5472: Der Chryser Myriadenführer Matallos.In den Schutzflehenden S. 264 folgt auf V. 437 die für unächt geltende Zeile:
tgt_text.5473: Der Leiden Unzahl schwillt, ein Strom, auf mich herein.Mit besonderem Fleiß und Scharfsinn sind die Sieben gegen Theben durchgearbeitet;
tgt_text.5474: es sind in ihnen Lücken, unächte Stellen, Umstellungen in nicht geringer Zahl nach­ gewiesen worden.
tgt_text.5475: Unzweifelhaft ist (S. 340) die mit V. 450 beginnende Gegenrede des Eteokles unvollständig;
tgt_text.5476: es fehlen einige (wohl sechs) Verse, die das vom Boten Gesagte aufnahmen und erwiederten.S.
tgt_text.5477: 341 folgt auf V. 477 die höchst müßige Zeile:
tgt_text.5478: Denn Angst und Zagen weckend prahlt er schon am Thor.Auf derselben Seite werden in der Gegenrede des Eteo­ kles nach dem sehr bezeichneten Schluß V. 491 noch folgende müßige Zeilen gelesen:
tgt_text.5479: So offenbart sich beider Götter Schutz und Gunst, Wir auf des Siegers Seite, auf des Besiegten sie.
tgt_text.5480: Und gleiches Loos einst werden beiden Kämpfenden, Wenn Zeus den Typho je im Kampf bezwungen hat, Und für Hyperbios nach des eignen Schildes Bild Der Zeus in seinem Wappen ein Beschützer ist.Namentlich die Schilderung des sechsten Helden (S. 343) ist in dem überlieferten Text voller Mißstände, denen zum Theil wenigstens durch Umstellungen abgeholfen worden ist.
tgt_text.5481: Vielleicht dürfte ein in der Uebersetzung ausgelassener Vers auf V. 541 folgen, so daß es heißen würde:
tgt_text.5482: Mit lautem Scheltwort frank und frei des Tydeus Kraft, Dem Adrastos danke alles Unheils bösen Rath.
tgt_text.5483: Selbst von den berühmten Versen (S. 344 V. 361)
tgt_text.5484: Denn nicht gerecht nur scheinen will er sondern sein, Aus tiefer Furche erntend seiner treuen Brust, Draus ihm hervorsprießt vielbewährten Rathes Frucht.
tgt_text.5485: scheint der zweite und dritte bedenklich, obschon die Stelle, die von den Zuschauern auf Aristeides gedeutet sein soll, schon hundert Jahr später so citirt wird, wie sie jetzt lautet.
tgt_text.5486: Auch die Schlußworte in Eteokles Rede (S. 346) sind mehr als bedenklich;
tgt_text.5487: seine Rede scheint mit V. 641 den stärkeren Schluß zu haben, als wenn er noch die drei fol­ genden Zeilen hinzuspricht.
tgt_text.5488: Doch habe ich sie nicht fortzu­ lassen gewagt.Das Ende der Tragödie (S. 364) hat die Uebersetzung als „Schluß späterer Hand" bezeichnet.
tgt_text.5489: Die Sprache dieser letzten Scene ist nicht von der Art des Aischylos;
tgt_text.5490: und sach­ lich ist es die Disposition der Sophokleischen Antigone, die, hier wenig angemessen, hinzugefügt ist.
tgt_text.5491: Denn am Schluß der Trilogie, wo nach so erschütternden Vorgängen ein be­ ruhigendes Ausklingen der tieferregten Empfindungen unent­ behrlich ist, kann der Dichter unmöglich einen neuen furcht­ baren Conflict eingeleitet haben, der dramatisch nicht zum Austrag kommen soll.
tgt_text.5492: Es ist möglich, daß man etwa in der Zeit des Redners Lykurgos zum Zweck einer neuen Auf­ führung dieser besonders beliebten Tragödie – die überdies nach dem späteren Maaß der Aufführungen zu kurz erschei­ nen mochte – eine freilich sehr ungeschickte Schlußscene an­ zufügen, für angemessen hielt.
tgt_text.5493: Der wirkliche Schluß der Tragödie war die Leichenklage der beiden Schwestern und der jetzt fehlende Trauergesang des geleitenden Chors,-unter dem die beiden Leichen, von den Schwestern gefolgt, hinaus- getragen wurden.
tgt_text.5494: Im Prometheus endlich ist S. 394 hinter V. 37 ein Vers ausgelassen, der eine müßige Wiederholung ist:
tgt_text.5495: Der doch den Menschen frevelnd dein Kleinod verrieth.
tgt_text.5496: Sodann folgt S. 401 hinter V. 208 die Zeile:
tgt_text.5497: Und Gaia, vieler Namen Eine Urgestalt, die irgend ein allzu kluger Mytholog hinzugefügt hat, ob­ schon Aischylos sichtlich die beiden Gestalten der ThemiS und Gaia durchaus von einander unterscheidet.Die große Bedeutsamkeit der Zeilen V. 451.452 (S. 411) fordert die Bemerkung, daß sie nach einer anderen Fassung übersetzt lauten würden:
tgt_text.5498: Der Schrift Gebrauch erfand ich, der Erinnerung Der sagenkundigen, Helferin aller Musenkunst.

tgt_text.0: THE object of these prose translations is to enable those who know some Greek to read the Greek of Æschylus correctly.
tgt_text.1: They have never dreamed of pretending to any value in artistic form.
tgt_text.2: No prose, however well it might be used, could ever represent such verse aesthetically;
tgt_text.4: and so long as verse affords the means of doing it, to seek the same end with a less effective instru- ment I have always looked upon as a mistaken aim.
tgt_text.5: Prose has a proper function of its own, a separate and different one-to show how the Greek is to be construed.
tgt_text.6: It is superior for that purpose, and should be content, I think, if it can achieve it without more offence than necessary.
tgt_text.7: The true spirit and effect are only in the power of verse to give;
tgt_text.8: but verse itself is not in a position to convey them until first it understands the meaning of the poet's words;
tgt_text.9: and it is in that preliminary business of explaining that a prose version has its legitimate and useful province.
tgt_text.10: Whether the text has been restored correctly, and the 'sense of it correctly rendered,-those are the two points on which a prose translation of a poem should be judged.
tgt_text.11: The numbering of lines adopted in this translation is that of Wecklein (1885), who counts them as they appear in the Medicean MS. (known as M).
tgt_text.12: Wecklein's is the best text for a scholar, but Weil's (Teubner) is good for ordinary purposes.
tgt_text.13: I have been careful to give the readings that differ from those of Wecklein and Well.
tgt_text.14: Many of these readings have been found since their editions, which represent the light of twenty years ago, were published;
tgt_text.15: and I hope it will be thought that the last twenty years have done much both for the text and the interpreta- tion of Æschylus.
tgt_text.16: Whenever they are likely to be un- familiar, the readings adopted are given in the margin;
tgt_text.17: and references to the Classical Review, which scholars can easily consult, have often enabled me to dispense with arguments in favour of them:
tgt_text.18: but in a book of this kind it was not convenient, and did not seem necessary, always to record the names of their discoverers.
tgt_text.19: Wecklein's Appendices give a complete record up to 1893;
tgt_text.20: and in the case of anything more recent, the author's name, when it is not my own, is mentioned.
tgt_text.21: It may be of service to students to add that the diction of The Persians is different from that of the other plays of Æschylus.
tgt_text.22: The characters are Persians, the scene is laid in their chief city, and the whole play reflects the manners and ideas of the East.
tgt_text.23: To suit the local colour, the language has an appropriate cast.
tgt_text.24: Æschylus makes his Persians speak in an archaic-sounding Ionic style, the Greek of Asia.
tgt_text.25: This effect is obtained partly by metre, eg. the use of long trochaics;
tgt_text.26: partly by forms of words and pronunciation (as veos ἐὼν νεὰ φρονεῖ, κυάνεον, εὐπέτεος, νεώς) ;
tgt_text.27: partly also by forms of phrase.
tgt_text.28: A similar effect was sought long afterwards by Timotheus, as we can now observe in his recently dis- covered dithyramb, the Πέρσαι.
tgt_text.29: There, describing the battle of Salamis, he puts broken Asiatic Greek into the mouth of a Persian.
tgt_text.31: In this volume the following plays:
tgt_text.32: Agamemnon, Choephoroe, Eumenides, Prometheus Bound, and The Sup- Pliants, were translated by Dr Walter Headlam, and have been already published separately.
tgt_text.33: The versions of The Persians and The Seven against Thebes are not from his hand, but the translator has been aided in the interpretation of various passages by notes which he left.
tgt_text.34: The text used is that of Wecklein (1885).
tgt_text.35: In a certain number of places other readings have been adopted, either due to Walter Headlam or known to have been approved by him.
tgt_text.36: These, with the exception of some differences in punctuation, will be found indicated in the margin.
tgt_text.37: In one or two lines of The Seven against Thebes where the text is corrupt, but not yet satisfactorily emended, a provisional reading, noted as such in the margin, has been adopted for the purpose of this translation.
tgt_text.38: PAGE INTRODUCTION ..... xiTHE SEVEN AGAINST THEBES ... 75THE SUPPLIANTS ....
tgt_text.40: ..... 273ÆSCHYLUS, son of Euphorion, was the eldest of the three great dramatists of Greece, Æschylus, Sophocles, Euripides.
tgt_text.41: By them the drama was developed from its early beginnings to the delicate, perhaps over- elaborated, art and semi-modern touch displayed in Euripides.
tgt_text.42: He was born in B.C. 525 at Eleusis in Attica, and died at Gela in Sicily in the year B.C. 456.
tgt_text.43: The recorded facts of his life are few, and even for these the authority is often doubtful.
tgt_text.44: For example, the reason for his going to Sicily-which he had probably visited earlier in his life at the invitation of Hiero, Tyrant of Syracuse-is variously narrated.
tgt_text.45: In the annual contests between the tragic poets, which at Athens were recognised and regulated by the State, his first success was obtained in B.C. 485.
tgt_text.46: In 472 he won the prize with the trilogy of which The Persians was one, and again in 477 with The Seven against Thebes.
tgt_text.47: In the history of the Grecian drama, a striking contribution on what may be termed the mechanical side was made by Æschylus, and proved of far- reaching importance.
tgt_text.48: Whereas in tragedy hitherto there had been only one actor and the chorus, he, by introducing a second actor, immensely extended the scope and opportunity for presenting dramatic situa- tions to an audience.
tgt_text.49: Seven plays remain to us as monuments of his genius.
tgt_text.50: In these there is observ- able a growth and progress in dramatic power, to which two principal causes may be noted as con- tributory.
tgt_text.51: Just as in England the Reformation, on the one hand, gave a stimulus to character and intellect, whilst on the other hand the discovery of the New World kindled the imagination by tales of .
tgt_text.52: voyages, or of lands favoured by Nature and rich in ancient wealth ;
tgt_text.53: to which causes the great outburst of literature in the era of Elizabeth was largely due;
tgt_text.54: so the heroic struggle of Greece against the aggressive power of Persia must have deeply influenced the imagination of the rising poet.
tgt_text.55: The battle of Marathon, in which Æschylus fought, and the defeat of the Persian fleet, are reflected in the vivid descrip- tion in The Persians of the sea-fight at Salamis ;
tgt_text.56: and were likely to produce that drama, separated only by a few years from The Persians, The Seven against Thebes, which represents a combat to the death of heroes,1 and is justly characterised by Aristophanes as δρᾶμα ῎Αρεως μεστόν, " a play crammed with the pomp of war."
tgt_text.57: The hardships, again, of the soldier on active service are described in the Agamemnon with a direct- ness which comes from experience of the realities of a campaign.
tgt_text.58: The second principal stimulus was, in the case of Æschylus, the contact of a mind naturally of a religious bent with the ideas and doctrines of the East.
tgt_text.59: The Ionian cities in Asia Minor were channels for the communication of such ideas, and there was in addition, at Eleusis, the birthplace of Æschylus, a ceremonial worship of Demeter and Persephone, embodied in the famous Eleusinian Mysteries.
tgt_text.60: With this cult of the Mother and Daughter, which had been one of the great recipients in Greece of new sacred rites borrowed from Egypt1 and connected with the worship of Isis, the family of Æschylus were, according to tradition, officially associated.
tgt_text.61: The acquaintance shown by Æschylus in The Persians with the distinctively Persian doctrines and philosophic view of Nature, as opposed to ideas elsewhere pre- vailing in the East, would of itself indicate a far more than superficial study of Oriental modes of thought.
tgt_text.62: From these considerations we may realise to some extent the mental equipment with which Æschylus came prepared to deal as a dramatist with the great problems which, under many diverse shapes, interest mankind.
tgt_text.63: In the Prometheus Bound the conflict between the Titanic benefactor of mankind and offended Heaven is shown only at one stage.
tgt_text.64: The dramatic grandeur of the scenes in which Prometheus is depicted unyielding, defiant, and heroic in his torment have always excited admiration ;
tgt_text.65: but the lines on which the final reconciliation was accom- plished can only be conjectured, since the remaining plays of the trilogy, though their titles have come down to us, are lost.
tgt_text.66: In his greatest achievement, the Oresteian trilogy, with which he gained the prize in B.C. 458, the traditional story of Agamemnon, as it presented itself to the mind of Æschylus, invited the solution of two difficulties.
tgt_text.67: In the first place, it was necessary to account for the fact that Agamemnon, the heroic leader,-distinguished by birth, wealth, and success in arms,-ended his career overwhelmed by apparently undeserved misfortune.
tgt_text.68: Secondly, in more general terms, as arising out of the particular cases of the fall of Troy, the death of Agamemnon, and the action of Orestes, it was necessary to justify the deal- ings of Heaven with mankind.
tgt_text.69: The transition from the Old Order to the New, which was exemplified in the Prometheus trilogy by the passing of the supremacy from Kronos (sovereign of the elder gods) to Zeus ;
tgt_text.70: and the mysterious limitation imposed by Destiny;
tgt_text.73: In that play the conflicting claims of the Furies (’Ερινύες), who belong to the old Elemental Powers,3 and of Apollo are referred to the arbitrament of Pallas.
tgt_text.74: Nor does Æschylus shrink from dissociating himself from traditional and current beliefs where the popular view, in his opinion, mistakes the attitude of the gods, or wrongly interprets it. "
tgt_text.75: Alone am I in my opinion, at variance with other men,”1 he says, in dissenting from the commonly accepted theory on the subject of prosperity.
tgt_text.76: It remains to be added that an interesting question as to the relation of AEschylus to the politics of his time is raised by the Eumenides.
tgt_text.77: It was produced at a time when party feeling ran high at Athens.
tgt_text.79: The senate of Areopagus had about this date been radically reformed 3 by the democratic party under Ephialtes and Pericles.
tgt_text.80: It had been the custom of the Areopagus to exercise a censorial power both over the Assembly and over the lives of the citizens.
tgt_text.81: This discretionary supervising authority was taken away, and it remained only as a court for trying cases of homicide.

tgt_text.798: he urges thee to abandon Obstinacy and seek that Counsel that is wise.
tgt_text.800: it is discreditable for the wise to err.
tgt_text.802: I knew the message that this fellow hath so loudly noised upon me, but to suffer ill entreatment from one's enemy is no humiliation.
tgt_text.803: So let be hurled upon me the forked ringlet of his fire and let the sky be set a- quivering with thunder and convulsion of the furious winds;
tgt_text.804: let the blast sway the earth by the roots from her founda- tions, and the wave of the sea with roughest surge and the courses of the stars in heaven confound together, and let him hurl my body into the bottomless pit of Tartarus with the circling whirl of stern Necessity:
tgt_text.805: to death, at all events, he never shall put me!
tgt_text.807: These are the very thoughts and speeches of the brain-struck!
tgt_text.808: How does it come short of stark insanity, this prayer of his ?
tgt_text.809: What abatement is there in his mad- ness ?
tgt_text.810: —Ye, however, at any rate, that are condoling in his tribulations, retire somewhere speedily from these regions, lest the harsh bellowing of the thunder strike your senses silly.
tgt_text.812: Give me some other words and exhortation, that you are likely to persuade me with !
tgt_text.813: for you do not surely imagine that this sweeping speech of yours is tolerable!
tgt_text.815: How can you dream of urging me to practise cowardice ?
tgt_text.816: I am content to share with him whatever Fate may have in store;
tgt_text.817: for I have learnt to abhor traitors, and there is no vice that I have greater loathing for than this !
tgt_text.819: Well, remember my warning, and when taken by the snaring hand of Ate, do not then blame Fortune;
tgt_text.820: never say that it was Zeus who cast you into trouble unforeseen;
tgt_text.821: nay, blame yourselves, for it is with knowledge and with no sudden surprise that ye will be entangled in the inextricable Net of Ate by your folly.
tgt_text.823: Ah now in deed, in word no more, the earth is rocked and the subterranean sound of thunder is booming at my side,1 the fiery streaks of lightning flashing out, and whirlwinds rolling up the eddying dust;
tgt_text.824: the blasts of all the winds leap wildly and display contention setting contrary against each other, and the sky is confounded with the sea:
tgt_text.825: so dire the rushing onset that proceeds from Zeus against me manifestly, working terror.
tgt_text.826: 0 thou holy one, my Mother, 0 thou Sky, revolving the common light of all the world, beholdest thou the injustice I am suffering ?
tgt_text.830: The palace of Xerxes at Susa.
tgt_text.832: The forenoon after the nocturnal vision of Atossa (v. 182 sqq.).
tgt_text.833: The Chorus, assembled in front of the palace (v. 144), give voice to their anxiety concerning the fate of the armada sent against Greece.
tgt_text.835: Behold in us the 'Trusty' remnant-as our name declares-of the Persians who are gone to the land of Hellas, and guardians of the opulent palace rich in gold;
tgt_text.836: whom king Xerxes, prince of Dareios' line, did himself select for our ripe years to watch over his country.
tgt_text.837: Now as to the return of our king and of his army rich in gold, my soul within me is at this present time disturbed, presaging disaster.
tgt_text.838: For all the strength of the Asian nation is gone abroad, and murmurs at having a new king,1 and neither any messenger nor any horseman arrives at the city, of the Persians who left Susa and went forth, and Ecbatana, and the ancient Cissian stronghold, some on horseback, some on shipboard, or as infantry forming close ranks of war.
tgt_text.839: Amistres, for instance, and Artaphrenes speed forth, and Megabates and Astaspes, Persian leaders;
tgt_text.840: kings subject to the Great King, overseers of a mighty host, masters of the bow and steed, terrible to look on and deadly in combat, in full confidence of spirit.
tgt_text.841: 1 Artembares too, who delights in horsemanship, and Masistres, and doughty Imæus, master of the bow, and Pharandakes, and Sosthanes driver of steeds.
tgt_text.842: Others did the great and fertilising river Nile send forth;
tgt_text.843: Susiskanes was there, Pegastagon of Egyptian family, and the prince of sacred Memphis, mighty Arsames, and Ariomardos, governor of ancient Thebes;
tgt_text.844: and inhabi- tants of a marshy region-rowers of ships-skilful, and in multitude innumerable.
tgt_text.845: And a crowd of soft-living Lydians, who keep in subjection a nation entirely land-faring, goes with them, whom Metrogathes and valiant Arcteus, ruling princes, and Sardis rich in gold send out, borne in many chariots, in two-shafted ranks and in three-shafted ranks, a sight terrible to see.
tgt_text.846: Set too are the borderers on sacred Tmolus on casting the yoke of servitude about Hellas,— Mardon, Tharybis, anvils of the spear, and men of Mysia whose weapon is the javelin.
tgt_text.847: Babylon too, the rich in gold, sends a mixed multitude in long array, some carried on ships, some trusting in their courage to draw the bow.
tgt_text.848: And the scimitar-armed peoples of all Asia go with them, under the dread mandates of the king.
tgt_text.849: So fair a flower of men of the Persian land is gone from it, in respect of whom all the country of Asia which reared them is constrained with vehement longing;
tgt_text.850: and parents and wives, as they count the days, tremble at the lengthening out of time.
tgt_text.851: The army of the king, which makes havoc of cities, by now has passed to the neighbouring land beyond the narrow sea, having crossed the strait of Helle daughter of Athamas on a cable-fastened pontoon-bridge, by casting a riveted causeway as a yoke upon the neck of Ocean.
tgt_text.852: Against a whole continent does the fiery leader of populous Asia direct his wondrous flock of men, in two divisions, with land-forces and on sea, putting his trust in his stalwart sturdy commanders-a being like unto the gods, of a race sprung from gold.
tgt_text.853: And flashing from his eyes the dark glance of a deadly python, with many a warrior and many a sailor, and urging forward his Syrian chariot, he is bringing against a people famous for the spear a nation in arms whose pride is the bow.
tgt_text.854: There is no one of such proved puissance as to with- stand the mighty torrent of men, and with secure defences keep back the resistless tide;
tgt_text.855: for the Persian army cannot be faced, and stout-hearted are their people.
tgt_text.856: But the beguiling Illusion of a god what mortal man shall escape?
tgt_text.857: Who is he that with agile foot is master of an easy leap [over the net] ?
tgt_text.858: Aye, for fawning at first upon him, as though with kind intent,1 it leads a man astray into the toils of Calamity, whence it is not possible for a mortal to escape and flee.
tgt_text.859: For by the gods' will since long ago Fate has been dominant, and has laid it upon the Persians to pursue wars that demolish towers, and shocks of cavalry in action, and destructions of cities.
tgt_text.860: Also they learned, putting trust in the slight structure of tackling and in contrivances for carrying men [over the waters], to look upon the ocean plain of the broad sea when it whitens beneath the furious blast.
tgt_text.861: Therefore my soul, shrouded in gloom, is racked with dread (Ah ! Ah!) for this Persian expedition, fearing lest the state may learn that the great city of the Susian district is made desolate of men, and the Cissians' town, as a crowd of women utter this cry Ah !
tgt_text.862: Ah !, may echo back the strain, and lest rending may fall on linen garments.
tgt_text.863: For all the host, driving steeds or tramping over the plain, is gone forth, like bees in a swarm, together with the captain-general of the expedition;
tgt_text.864: having crossed over the projecting arm of the sea,1 now bridged over, which is common to both continents.
tgt_text.865: And by reason of yearning for absent warriors couches, are filled with weeping;
tgt_text.866: and Persian wives, indulging their grief,2 each one of them, having sent away [to the war] her gallant armed consort, is left solitary.
tgt_text.867: But come, Persians, let us seat ourselves beneath the shade of this ancient palace and take good counsel from the depths of thought (and need there is for it), as to how haply fares Xerxes our king of Dareios' line, of the race of [Perseus] our common ancestor-whether it is the drawing of the bow that conquers, or has the power of the pointed spear the mastery ?
tgt_text.868: But here is hasting forth an effulgence like to the eyes of gods, the Mother of the King, my Queen;
tgt_text.870: And fitting also is it that we all address her in words of salutation.
tgt_text.871: Queen supreme of Persia's deep-girt women, venerable mother of Xerxes, wife to Dareios, hail!
tgt_text.872: Consort wert thou of the Persian's god;
tgt_text.873: and mother art thou of a god—unless its ancient happy fortune is now departed from the host.
tgt_text.875: In just that fear did I leave the gold-appointed palace and the bridal-chamber which I shared with Dareios, and now come hither.
tgt_text.876: My thoughts are racking ray heart;
tgt_text.877: and to you, ray friends, will I tell ray tale, being by no means without misgiving about myself, in dread lest great Good Fortune,1 raising over the earth the dust [of a military advance], shall have overturned with its foot the [fabric of]
tgt_text.878: Prosperity which Dareios reared not unaided by some god.
tgt_text.879: Therefore is there a twofold anxious thought, inexpressible, in my mind-not to honour with reverence a mass of riches lacking men ;
tgt_text.880: and again, that light shines not equal to their strength on men lacking wealth.
tgt_text.881: Our wealth, indeed, is beyond cavil, but there is alarm concerning our eye-for I hold the master's presence to be the eye of the palace- wherefore, Persians, since these things are so, lend me, ye aged Trusty ones, your counsel.
tgt_text.882: For in my case all sound resolutions are dependent upon you.
tgt_text.884: Be well assured, Queen of this land, not twice hast thou to indicate either word or deed [to us] respecting matters in which Power is wont to lead the way ;
tgt_text.885: for loyal to thy interests are we whom thou summonest as counsellors in these affairs.
tgt_text.887: By many a dream in the night-time have I been haunted ever since my son, having fitted out an armada, went hence with design to ravage the Ionians' land.
tgt_text.888: But never saw I aught so clear as in the night just passed-and I will tell it to thee.
tgt_text.889: There seemed to appear before me two women in fair attire, one apparelled in Persian raiment, the other in Dorian, the twain pre-eminent in stature beyond those living now, flawless in beauty, and sisters of the same family.
tgt_text.890: The country they inhabited was in the case of one sister, Hellas—she having acquired it by lot—in the case of the other, barbarian soil.
tgt_text.891: These twain, as I thought I perceived, were pursuing a quarrel one with the other;
tgt_text.892: and my son, having become aware of it, was seeking to check and to pacify them, and yokes the pair to a chariot and places harness over their necks.
tgt_text.893: And one of them towered loftily in these trappings, and kept her mouth tractable in the reins;
tgt_text.894: but the other began to plunge, and with her hands tears in pieces the harness of the chariot, and drags it furiously along with her, heeding not the bit, and snaps the yoke asunder.
tgt_text.895: Then falls my son, and his father Dareios stands beside commiserating him.
tgt_text.896: And Xerxes, when he perceives him, rends his robes around his body.
tgt_text.897: These things I tell you I beheld in the night;
tgt_text.898: but when I had arisen, and touched with my hands the fair waters of a spring, I took my station at an altar with incense in my hand, intending to offer a sacred mixture to the divinities who avert evil, for whom these ceremonies are proper.
tgt_text.899: But I see an eagle fleeing for refuge to the altar of Phcebus, -and from terror I stood speechless, my friends,-and after that I see a hawk rushing with outstretched wings upon him, and with his talons plucking at his head;
tgt_text.900: and the eagle did nothing but cower down and yield his body.
tgt_text.901: This was terrifying for me to see, and so it is for you to hear.
tgt_text.902: For know ye well that my son, should he be success- ful, would be regarded with awe, and supposing he should not be successful,—he1 cannot be called to account by the state, and if he escapes alive, he is, in any event, the ruler of this land.
tgt_text.904: We desire not, 0 Mother, either to alarm thee unduly by our words, or unduly to raise thy hopes;
tgt_text.905: but if thou didst see anything sinister, thou shouldst supplicate the gods with prayer, and beseech diversion of these evils, and that all good things may be fulfilled for thyself and thy children and for the city and for all thy friends.
tgt_text.906: And in the second place it is proper that thou pour a libation to the earth and to the dead;
tgt_text.907: and in propitiatory wise do thou ask this boon of thy spouse Dareios, whom thou declarest thou didst see by night,-to send good things for thee and for thy son to the light of day from beneath the earth;
tgt_text.908: and [ask that] the reverse of this, detained below the earth, may fade away in darkness.
tgt_text.909: Thus I advise thee with kindly intent, guided only by the promptings of my mind.
tgt_text.910: And our interpretation is that in all ways a good issue will be brought to pass for thee in this matter.
tgt_text.912: With kind intent, I know, to my son and to my house, didst thou, the first interpreter of these visions, determine thus their import.
tgt_text.913: May what is good come to pass.
tgt_text.914: And all these things, as thou dost enjoin, will I per- form for the gods and for those dear to me beneath the earth when I have gone into the palace.
tgt_text.915: But now on the following points, my friends, I wish to be exactly informed;
tgt_text.917: In what part of the world do they say Athens is situated ?
tgt_text.919: Far hence towards the west, where are the waning fires1 of our Lord the Sun.Atossa.
tgt_text.920: Was then my son so eager to make this city his prey?
tgt_text.922: Yes, for thus would all Hellas become subject to the Great King.
tgt_text.924: Is theirs an army with so full a complement of men?
tgt_text.926: Aye, and an army of such quality as once wrought havoc on the Medes.
tgt_text.928: And what else have they besides?
tgt_text.929: Is there sufficing wealth in their homes ?
tgt_text.931: They have of silver, as one might say, a spring;
tgt_text.934: Is the arrow-point drawn by the bow to be seen in their hands ?
tgt_text.937: They have spears for close fighting, and harness for the shield.
tgt_text.939: Who is over them as master, and dominates the host?
tgt_text.941: To no man are they reckoned slaves or in subjection.
tgt_text.943: So [stoutly] that they destroyed a large and goodly army of Dareios.
tgt_text.945: Terrible, truly, are thy words for the parents of those who have gone forth to reflect upon.
tgt_text.947: Stay, thou wilt soon, as I think, know all for certain;
tgt_text.948: for the [fashion of] running of this man coming is plain to recognise as Persian;
tgt_text.949: and he brings clear tidings of something, be it good or ill.
tgt_text.952: 0 land of Persia, and mighty haven of wealth, how at a single stroke is all your great prosperity destroyed, and the flower of the Persians fallen and gone !
tgt_text.954: a thankless office it is to be the first to bring tidings of disaster;
tgt_text.955: yet needs must I unfold all that has happened to the Persians.
tgt_text.956: The whole barbarian host has perished.
tgt_text.958: Grievous, grievous disaster, all unexpected, and miserable!
tgt_text.959: Alas, Persians, bathe your eyes in tears, now that of this disaster ye hear.
tgt_text.961: Yes, [hearing] that all with them is quite destroyed, and that I myself behold the day of my return beyond my expectation.
tgt_text.963: Too long indeed, as I may say, life doth now appear to us old men, that we should hear of this un- expected calamity.
tgt_text.965: And, look you, Persians, I being present then can tell you, not from hearing others' talk, what evil fate was dealt out.
tgt_text.968: In vain did the mingled multitude of shafts go from the land of Asia against an enemy's country-the land of Hellas.
tgt_text.970: The shores of Salamis, and every neighbour- ing place, are full of dead, who perished in evil case.
tgt_text.973: Thy words imply that the bodies of those dear to us are drifting, lifeless, sea-beaten, water- logged, on the tides as they ebb and flow.
tgt_text.976: Yes, for our bows availed nought, and our whole host has perished, beaten down by charges amidships of [the enemy's] vessels.
tgt_text.978: Wail aloud for the luckless Persians a cry of woe with mournful sound, for their utter misfortune.
tgt_text.979: Alas for the destruction of the host!
tgt_text.981: 0 name of Salamis, most hateful to our ears !
tgt_text.983: how I groan when I remember Athens !
tgt_text.985: Aye, hateful is Athens to her foes.
tgt_text.986: Well may you call to mind how many Persian women she made widows and husbandless, with nought for us to set down as gain.
tgt_text.988: Long have I kept silence in my misery, shocked at the ills which have befallen us;
tgt_text.989: for this sad event is too great for me to speak of, or inquire the details.
tgt_text.990: Neverthe- less mortals must endure afflictions when the gods award them.
tgt_text.991: Do thou compose thyself, and, unfolding all that happened, even though thou groanest at the evil of it, speak out.
tgt_text.992: Who is there that is not dead ?
tgt_text.993: Whom, of the leaders of the host, are we to bewail as having been appointed to bear the baton of command and leaving by his death a 300 rank forlorn without its chief?
tgt_text.995: Xerxes himself is alive and beholds the light.
tgt_text.997: A great light to my house, and a brightly dawning day after black night, are in these words of thine!
tgt_text.999: But Artembares, leader of a myriad horse, is being dashed against the rocky shores of Sileniae.
tgt_text.1000: And the chiliarch Dadakes beneath the shock of a spear leapt with a light spring overboard.
tgt_text.1001: Tenagon, too, the true-born chieftain of the Bactrians, is moving to and fro about the surf-beaten isle of Aias.
tgt_text.1002: Lilaios and Arsames and, thirdly, Argestes, around the dove-breeding island keep butting, these three, helplessly against the unyielding shore.
tgt_text.1003: Arcteus too, whose dwelling is nigh unto the waters of Egyptian Nile, Adeues, and, thirdly, t Phreseues, t Phar- nuchos, these fell from one vessel.
tgt_text.1004: Matallos of Chrysa, commander of ten thousand, leader of thirty thousand black cavalry, soaked in death his thick and bushy auburn beard, changing its colour with a staining of dark purple.
tgt_text.1005: And Magian Arabos perished there, and Artabes the Bactrian, a settler now in a rugged land.
tgt_text.1006: Amistris, and Amphistreus wielder of an active spear, and gallant Ariomardos—a cause of grief [by his death] to Sardis—and Sisames the Mysian, and Tharybis of Lyrnaian race, commander of five times fifty ships, a warrior of goodly presence, lies dead, unhappy man, in sorely wretched case.
tgt_text.1007: And a Syennesis, foremost in courage, governor of the Cilicians, fell gloriously, after giving more trouble to the foe than any other one man.
tgt_text.1008: Of such among our leaders have I now made mention.
tgt_text.1009: I report but a few out of the many misfortunes which I have in mind.
tgt_text.1012: I hear in this the very height of disaster-a disgrace to the Persians, and [a cause for] shrill lamentations.
tgt_text.1013: But turn thou back again, and tell me this,
tgt_text.1014: How great was the number of the Greek vessels that they ventured to join battle with the Persian armament by charging with their ships'-beaks upon it ?
tgt_text.1016: As to numbers, be well assured that the bar- barians1 had the advantage in ships;
tgt_text.1017: for on the Greek side the whole numbers came to three divisions of thirty vessels, and there was besides these a select division of ten.
tgt_text.1018: But Xerxes had, for I know, a thousand in number of which he • was commander, and those [besides] of superior class in speed were two hundred and seven;
tgt_text.1019: this is the tale of them.
tgt_text.1020: You do not think us the inferior force in this engagement ?
tgt_text.1021: No, it was some divinity that destroyed the host, having depressed the scales of fortune with a weight against our side.
tgt_text.1022: The gods keep safe the city of their goddess Pallas.
tgt_text.1026: Yes, for whilst her warriors live she has a sure protection.
tgt_text.1028: Now tell me what was the beginning of the naval encounter.
tgt_text.1029: Who were they who made the first move in the fight?
tgt_text.1031: Or my son, from a sense of exultation at the number of his ships ?
tgt_text.1033: Some fiend it was, 0 mistress, or evil spirit that appeared from somewhere, who began all the mischief.
tgt_text.1034: A Greek, who came from the Athenian host, told thy son Xerxes that if the darkness of black night should come the Greeks would not stand fast, but, leaping on to the thwarts of their vessels, would, each taking his own direction, endeavour to save their lives by stealthy flight.
tgt_text.1035: And he, as soon as he heard this, not realising the wile of the Greek nor the jealousy of the gods, publishes to all the captains the following order-when the sun should have ceased to illumine the earth with his rays and darkness should have laid hold on the temple of the sky, then to draw up vessels in close order arranged in three lines to guard the sea-exits and the murmuring straits ;
tgt_text.1036: and [to station] other vessels in a circle round about the isle of Aias;
tgt_text.1037: understanding that, if the Greeks shall escape an evil fate by finding some means of escape for their ships, without being discovered, it has been decreed that they shall all be deprived of their heads.
tgt_text.1038: Such were his words, prompted by much confidence of mind, since he knew not what was appointed by the gods to come to pass.
tgt_text.1039: And the Persian troops in orderly fashion and disciplined spirit set about preparing an evening meal, and each seaman saw to the lashing of his oar about the nicely fitted thole-pin.
tgt_text.1040: Then, when the light of the sun had waned and night was coming on, every master of an oar went to his ship, and every master of weapons.
tgt_text.1041: And one line of warships kept cheering on another line and [the Persians] make sail even as each man had orders, and the livelong night ship-captains kept all the crews working their vessels backwards and forwards.
tgt_text.1042: But though night began to draw off, yet the Greek host made nowhere any kind of attempt at a stealthy escape.
tgt_text.1043: When, however, day with its white steeds, radiant to behold, had occupied all the earth, first of all a cheer from the Greeks rang loudly like a chant of triumph, and shrill and clear from the island crags Echo returned the cry.
tgt_text.1044: And fear was in the hearts of all the barbarians, finding themselves mistaken;
tgt_text.1045: for the Greeks were then chanting a solemn pæan not as seeking to escape, but as advancing to battle with daring courage.
tgt_text.1046: Next a bugle with its call fired all their line to action, and at once with foaming dash of oars in unison they smote, to the word of command, the resounding brine.
tgt_text.1047: And rapidly the whole of them came plain into view.
tgt_text.1048: The right wing in good order led on foremost, and after that their whole armament was coming on against us, and at the same time a mighty shout could be heard, "Sons of the Greeks, advance !
tgt_text.1049: Deliver your country, deliver your children and your wives, the temples of your fathers' gods, the tombs of your ancestors.
tgt_text.1050: Now is the contest which decides all!"
tgt_text.1051: And then a confused noise of Persian tongues met them from our line, and no longer was it a time for inaction, but forthwith ship against ship struck its armoured prow.
tgt_text.1052: A Greek vessel commenced the charge, and breaks off the whole stern part of a Phoenician ship, and each [captain] then steered his bark against some other vessel.
tgt_text.1053: At first indeed the torrent of the Persian armament held its own.
tgt_text.1054: But since the multitude of our ships was crowded in the narrows, and they could give no assistance the one to the other but [on the contrary] were rammed by the brazen- pointed beaks of their friends, they splintered their whole equipment of oars,-the Greek ships, too, all around them noting their opportunity, kept charging them on every side, -and the hulls of our vessels began to be capsized nor was the sea any longer visible, so choked was it with wrecks and slaughtered men;
tgt_text.1055: and the shores and the reefs were full of them.
tgt_text.1056: Then in rout and confusion every ship, as many as there were of the barbarian armament, sought to row away.
tgt_text.1057: But the Greeks kept striking and hewing, as though we were tunnies or some draught of fish, with fragments of broken oars and splinters of wreckage;
tgt_text.1058: and cries of anguish filled the open sea with shrieks, until the appearance of dark night broke off [the combat].
tgt_text.1059: Now the total of our misfortunes, not even were I to recite the list of them for ten days, could I complete for thee;
tgt_text.1060: for be well assured that never on a single day died so great a number of men.
tgt_text.1063: in very truth a mighty sea of troubles has burst over the Persians and all the barbarian race.
tgt_text.1065: Know well that their trouble reaches not yet the half.
tgt_text.1066: Such an visitation of sufferings came upon them as by balance to draw, even twice over, an equal weight with these [which I have pictured].
tgt_text.1068: What turn of fortune could be yet more hateful than this ?
tgt_text.1069: Say what the event is which thou declarest came to the host, inclining the scale far on the side of evil.
tgt_text.1071: As many of the Persians as were in the very flower of life and most valiant in spirit and distinguished by noble birth, and were ever amongst the foremost in loyalty to the monarch himself, are dead in shameful plight by a most inglorious doom.
tgt_text.1074: grieved am I, my friends, at a grievous event.
tgt_text.1075: But by what nature of doom sayest thou they are lost to us ?
tgt_text.1077: An island there is, lying off Salamis-in- significant in size, a dangerous anchorage for ships-which Pan who loves the dance doth ofttimes visit, haunting the sea-beach thereof.
tgt_text.1078: Thither Xerxes sends these [chosen warriors] in order that, whenever their foes wrecked from out their ships should attempt to win safe to the island, they might make an easy prey of the Greek soldiery and slay them;
tgt_text.1079: and help their own comrades to safety from out the sea-way—sadly at fault in his opinion of the future:
tgt_text.1080: for when some god had given the glory of [victory in] the sea- fight to the Greeks, that same day having secured their bodies with brazen armour they set to leaping out of their ships and forming a circle round about the entire island, so that [the Persian band] were at a loss whither to turn.
tgt_text.1081: For oft they were struck by stones thrown by hand and arrows from the bow-string fell upon and destroyed them ;
tgt_text.1082: and at last [ the Greeks] charging upon them with a simul- taneous cheer strike them down, and hack in pieces the limbs of the unhappy men, till they had utterly destroyed the life in all of them.
tgt_text.1083: And Xerxes groaned aloud when he saw the depth of his calamities, for he had a seat in full view of all the army-a'high knoll close to the ocean brine;
