tgt_text.1401: I am dismayed, astonied, that they follow1 not in thy train screened by tents borne on wheels.
tgt_text.1403: [Vain thy longing,] for they who were the leaders 2 of the army are gone.
tgt_text.1411: Alas, alas, Divinities, ye caused us an unlooked- for disaster, that makes clear to all men how watchful is the eye of Calamity.
tgt_text.1414: What turns of fortune are there in 1 life !
tgt_text.1416: We are struck down, 'tis clearly so,Xerxes.
tgt_text.1417: Unlooked-for sorrows, unlooked-for sorrows !Chorus. — having encountered Ionian seamen in an evil hour.
tgt_text.1418: Unfortunate indeed in war are the Persian nation.
tgt_text.1421: Unhappy man, I am struck down in the matter of all my huge army.
tgt_text.1423: What is there then of the Persians, 0 thou of great ill-fortune, that is not destroyed ?
tgt_text.1425: See'st thou what is left of my vesture (pointing to it)-Chorus.
tgt_text.1428: What is it thou sayest is saved ?
tgt_text.1430: Little enough out of so much.
tgt_text.1432: We are in lack of supporters.
tgt_text.1434: The Ionian people shrinks not from the fray.
tgt_text.1437: I was witness of an unlooked- for calamity.
tgt_text.1439: Is it of the lines of thy naval host turned to flight that thou wilt speak ?
tgt_text.1441: Aye, and I rent my robes at the advent of disaster.
tgt_text.1446: True, for twofold are our woes, and threefold.
tgt_text.1449: but a joy to our enemies.
tgt_text.1451: And our strength has been maimed,Chorus.
tgt_text.1452: bythe disaster at sea of thy friends.
tgt_text.1454: Shed tears, tears for the calamity;
tgt_text.1460: Cry aloud now in response to me.
tgt_text.1462: A wretched offering to a wretched man from wretched men!
tgt_text.1464: Wail aloud, making the sound in unison.
tgt_text.1469: much indeed do I grieve over this.
tgt_text.1471: Beat, beat on [thy head], and groan aloud for my sake.
tgt_text.1475: Cry aloud now in response to me.
tgt_text.1479: Raise thy voice now with wailing.
tgt_text.1482: Again shall fall confusedly blows that bruise and call forth shrieks of pain.* Xerxes.
tgt_text.1483: Beat thy breast too, and cry aloud the Mysian lament,Xerxes.
tgt_text.1484: andmake havoc, I bid you, of the white hair of thy beard,Chorus.
tgt_text.1485: With clutching hands [I do so] 'mid cries of anguish.
tgt_text.1486: Xerxes and utter a shrill note,Chorus.
tgt_text.1488: andwith thy fingers rend thy robes about thy breast,Xerxes.
tgt_text.1489: andpluck thy hair, and lament over the army.
tgt_text.1491: With clutching hands [I do so] 'mid cries of anguish.
tgt_text.1497: Cry aloud now in response to me.
tgt_text.1502: Go towards your homes with sounds of mourning,Chorus.
tgt_text.1503: Alas, Persian land, so sad now to tread !Xerxes.
tgt_text.1510: Utter aloud your lament, as ye step delicately onward.
tgt_text.1512: Alas, Persian land, now so sad to tread!
tgt_text.1516: in three-banked galleys (ah me !) all perished ... !
tgt_text.1518: I will escort thee with mournful sounds of woe.
tgt_text.1519: ETEOCLES, brother to Polynices, and ruler of Thebes.
tgt_text.1520: A MESSENGER, employed as a scout.
tgt_text.1525: The morning of the day on which the seven champions of the besieging Argive army have resolved on an assault.
tgt_text.1526: ETEOCLES, the present ruler of Thebes, whilst awaiting the return of the messenger he has sent out to reconnoitre, addresses an assemblage of Theban citizens.
tgt_text.1528: Citizens of Cadmus, it is fitting that whosoe'er at the helm of the [ship of]
tgt_text.1529: State watches over affairs, managing the rudder without closing his eyelids in slumber, should speak as the occasion demands.
tgt_text.1530: For if we should meet with success, the cause of it would be [put to the credit] of Heaven ;
tgt_text.1531: but if on the contrary-which may God forbid-disaster should occur, Eteocles alone would be much bruited up and down the city by the townsmen at the beginning of many a murmuring speech and lamentation;
tgt_text.1532: of which may Zeus prove to the Cadmean city rightly named Averter.
tgt_text.1533: You it now behoves-both him that yet falls short of 10 manhood's prime, and him that is past it but yet keeps up a vigorous growth of body, and'(as is only right) each one of the age for military service,1—to succour his city and the altars of his ancestral gods, so that their worship be not ever destroyed, and his children, and the earth his mother, kindliest nurse;
tgt_text.1534: for she, taking upon herself all the cumber of their nurture, reared up young creatures moving on her genial plain to be a shield-bearing people, that ye might prove yourselves worthy of trust at the present need.
tgt_text.1535: So now until to-day Heaven inclines in our favour;
tgt_text.1536: for during all this time [the fortune of] war has mostly gone well for the besieged;
tgt_text.1537: but now, as declares the seer, the feeder of birds who by ear and judgment, without the aid of fire, revolves [the import of] birds of omen with unerring art-he who is master of that kind of divination tells us that an Achaean attack, greater than any yet, is being discussed in the night and that they will plan an assault upon the city.
tgt_text.1538: Come, hasten all ye to the battlements and to the gates of the defences !
tgt_text.1539: Make speed equipped in full armour, man the breast-works, and, taking each his station on the platforms of the towers, stand fast and be of good courage;
tgt_text.1540: nor tremble over-much at the crowd of aliens.
tgt_text.1541: Heaven will guide aright the issue.
tgt_text.1542: I for my part, also, sent out scouts and observers of their host, who are, I am confident, on no useless errand;
tgt_text.1543: and, when I hear their report, I shall in no wise be caught by stratagem.
tgt_text.1545: Eteocles, most noble prince of the Cadmeans, I am returned bringing clear tidings of what is going forward yonder in the host;
tgt_text.1546: and am myself eye-witness of the facts.
tgt_text.1547: Seven warriors, gallant captains, having cut a bull's throat over a shield inlaid with metal 2 and touching with their hands the bull's blood, called to witness Ares, and Enyo, and Terror that rejoiceth in slaughter, that, either they would sack the citadel of the Cadmeans bringing destruction upon it by force of arms, or in death would mingle their blood with this soil.
tgt_text.1548: And memorials of themselves, destined for their homes, were they hanging for their parents upon the chariot of Adrastos, shedding tears-though no sound of complaint was on their lips;
tgt_text.1549: for a spirit of iron determina- tion as of lions with battle in their eyes was inspiring them, kindling them with valour.
tgt_text.1550: And of this the report is not delayed by interval of time;
tgt_text.1551: for I left them in the act of drawing lots as to how each of them, receiving his post by the lot, should lead his company against our gates.
tgt_text.1552: There- fore do thou marshal with speed our chosen bravest warriors at the exits of the city-gates.
tgt_text.1553: For already nigh at hand the Argive army in full array is advancing, is raising the dust, and white foam from their horses' lungs is marking the plain with spots.
tgt_text.1554: Do thou, like a good ship’s-helmsman, secure the citadel before the blast of war rushes down;
tgt_text.1555: for the surge of their host is roaring over the land.
tgt_text.1556: So do thou in respect of this seize occasion, as may be most rapid.
tgt_text.1557: I too, for what remains, will keep a trusty eye on the watch all day, and thou by knowledge from clear report of what goes on without the gates shalt be safe from harm.
tgt_text.1559: 0 Zeus, and Earth, and Gods who guard our city, and thou Curse the mighty Erinys of my sire, extirpate not root and branch, I pray, in the utter ruin of capture by an enemy, our city which utters the speech of Hellas and the chambers of our homes!
tgt_text.1560: Let none ever restrain a free land and Cadmus' city with the yoke of slavery;
tgt_text.1562: And herein I am confident that I voice our common interest:
tgt_text.1563: for a city which prospers pays worship to her gods.
tgt_text.1565: I cry aloud for great and terrifying woes!
tgt_text.1566: The army is let loose, and has left its camp.
tgt_text.1567: Yonder is stream- ing a mass of mounted folk in advance.
tgt_text.1568: Dust. high in air, messenger though voiceless yet clear and true, convinces me.
tgt_text.1569: The rattle of shields stuns me,1 ... the noise of arms upon the plain ... wings its way with a din that sounds in my ears, and roars like a resistless torrent dashing down a mountain side.
tgt_text.1570: (0 gods and goddesses, avert the rising evil !)
tgt_text.1571: With a shout that comes over the walls the argent-shielded folk are on the move, pressing forward in orderly array against the city.
tgt_text.1573: Who of the gods or goddesses will come to our aid ?
tgt_text.1574: Shall 1 prostrate myself before the images of the divinities ?
tgt_text.1576: 'Tis full time to cling to the images.
tgt_text.1578: Hear ye, or hear ye not the noise of shields ?
tgt_text.1579: When, if not now, shall we busy ourselves with suppliant rites 2 of peplus and of garland?
tgt_text.1581: That was never the clash of a single spear!
tgt_text.1584: wilt thou desert thine own city, 0 Ares, old inhabitant of the land ?
tgt_text.1585: O God of the golden helm, look thou, look thou upon the city which once thou didst hold dear.
tgt_text.1586: Ye gods, who guard our land, come all ye to us:
tgt_text.1587: look upon a company of maidens who beseech ye in dread of slavery.
tgt_text.1588: For around the city, gathered by the blasts of no war, a wave of slanting-crested warriors is dashing,—O Zeus, father all-accomplishing, save us from capture by the foemen —and the Argives are encompassing the citadel of Cadmus, and there is a clangour1 of martial weapons, aye, and in the horses' mouths bridles are rattling in deadly chorus.
tgt_text.1589: And seven leaders, conspicu- ous in the host for their lancer's harness, are standing hard by our seventh gate, having received their posts by lot.
tgt_text.1590: And thou, 0 Pallas, Zeus-born Power that loves the fray, do thou prove thyself deliverer of our city;
tgt_text.1591: and thou, Poseidon, steeded monarch who rulest the ocean with fish- spearing trident, grant release from our terrors.
tgt_text.1592: And thou, O Ares, (alas, alas !), do thou protect the city named from Cadmus, and manifest thyself her guardian kinsman.
tgt_text.1593: And thou, 0 Aphrodite, do thou as befits the ancestress of our race keep back the foe :
tgt_text.1594: for of thy blood are we sprung :
tgt_text.1595: crying aloud 2 we approach thee with prayers to thy god- head.
tgt_text.1596: And thou, 0 Lycian king, prove thyself a very wolf the hostile army, [in response] to the voice 3 of our sigh- ings.
tgt_text.1597: And thou, 0 virgin daughter of Latona, do thou make ready thy bow.
tgt_text.1599: I hear a din of chariots round about the city, (0 queen Hera !) the axle-boxes of weighed-down axles scream, (0 Artemis beloved !) ah me, ah me !
tgt_text.1600: and the air a-quiver with spears is in a frenzy.
tgt_text.1603: Whither will Heaven yet direct the issue ?
tgt_text.1604: Ah me, ah me A shower of stones is coming upon the battlements struck from afar, (0 Apollo beloved !) there is a clatter at the gates of brass-bound shields-child of Zeus, from whom comes the sacred decision ending the strife in battle, and thou, 0 Onca, blest queen established before our city, come to the rescue of our seven-gated town.
tgt_text.1605: O divinities all-sufficing, 0 ye perfect guardian gods and oddesses of this land's defences, betray not the war-wearied town to an army of outlandish speech,-Hear ye, hear fully the prayers of maidens which they offer with outstretched hands
tgt_text.1606: But,2 0 divinities beloved, encompassing the city as its deliverers show yourselves friendly to it.
tgt_text.1607: Take thought of the ceremonies publicly performed, and taking thought of them protect them.
tgt_text.1608: Aye, and be ye mindful, I pray, of the city-festivals with abundant sacrifice.
tgt_text.1610: You I ask, you intolerable creatures, Is it the best [method of bringing] safety to the city and confidence to this army here beleaguered, that you should thus prostrated before the images of our tutelary gods cry aloud and shriek, 0 abominations of the self-controlled ?
tgt_text.1611: Neither in dangers nor in welcome prosperity may I ever be companion of the female sex;
tgt_text.1612: for a woman, when she has her way, is a bold thing impossible to live with, and when she is terrified, is a yet greater mischief to home and city.
tgt_text.1613: So now ye, by making these flights hither and thither, inspire with your clamour spiritless cowardice in the citizens;
tgt_text.1614: and, though things outside are going as much as possible in our favour, yet we by our own folk are being ruined from within.
tgt_text.1615: Now if there be any that will not give ear to my authority-be it man or woman or aught neutral -against them shall a vote of death be cast,3 and in no wise shall [the condemned one] escape death from stoning by the people.
tgt_text.1616: Outside matters are a man's business;
tgt_text.1617: let not a woman advise as to them.
tgt_text.1618: Remain thou within doors, and create not mischief.
tgt_text.1619: Hearest thou or nearest thou not, or am I speaking to a deaf woman ?
tgt_text.1621: 0 beloved son of Oedipus, I shuddered at hearing the din of rumbling chariots, when the naves screamed as the wheels revolved, and the noise1 of the guides in the horses' mouths-their fire-forged bridles.
tgt_text.1624: Surely the sailor never yet found means of safety by fleeing from the helm to the bows when his ship was labouring in the ocean waves ?
tgt_text.1626: But it was in reliance upon the gods that I came out from the house 2 to the ancient images of the divinities, when the roar of the deadly pelting storm arose at our gates:
tgt_text.1627: then indeed was I impelled by terror to supplications of the gods that they would extend their aid to the city.
tgt_text.1629: Let your prayer be that the defences may keep out the foe.
tgt_text.1630: This will be for the gods to grant.
tgt_text.1631: But, all the same, 'tis said that when a city is taken, her gods desert her.
tgt_text.1633: Never during my life may this assemblage of divinities desert us:
tgt_text.1634: never may I live to see this city overrun by conquerors and their army kindling it with destructive flames.
tgt_text.1636: I pray you be not ill-advised in thus calling to the gods.
tgt_text.1637: Obedience is the mother of Success, spouse of one who gives safety.
tgt_text.1641: Yet is the might of Heaven above all:
tgt_text.1642: and doth oft in dangers, even after sore distress, lift the cloud of despair hanging over men's eyes.
tgt_text.1644: Men's business it is to manage sacrifices and consultations of the gods, when about to try the strength of their foes ;
tgt_text.1645: but thy part it is to keep silence and remain within the chambers.
tgt_text.1647: Through the gods it is that we enjoy a city unconquered, and that our defences keep off a horde of ill-wishers.
tgt_text.1648: What just censure objects to this [attitude of ours] ?
tgt_text.1650: I have no objection to your honouring the race of gods.
tgt_text.1651: But, that ye may not make the citizens lose heart, be quiet ;
tgt_text.1652: and do not over-much give way to terror.
tgt_text.1654: It was on hearing a sudden din that in trembling fear I came all in confusion to the acropolis, the abode of honour.
tgt_text.1656: Do not ye, if ye hear of any dying or wounded, be eager to receive them with cries of sorrow.
tgt_text.1657: For the slaughter of men is that whereon Ares is maintained.
tgt_text.1660: I hear the neighing of steeds.
tgt_text.1662: Though thou hearest it, show not over-plainly that thou hearest.
tgt_text.1664: The city groans from earth beneath, as though men were surrounding it.
tgt_text.1666: Then it is enough that I should take measures about this.
tgt_text.1669: a battering is increasing at the gates.
tgt_text.1671: Will you keep silence, and say nought about it up and down the city ?
tgt_text.1673: 0 ye assembled gods, desert not our defences.
tgt_text.1675: Will you be silent-a curse on you,—and refrain from this talk ?
tgt_text.1677: Gods of our city, let me not meet with a slave's fate.
tgt_text.1679: 'Tis thou thyself that art like to enslave both me and the whole city.
tgt_text.1681: 0 almighty Zeus, turn thy bolt against our enemies.
tgt_text.1682: Eteocles. 0 Zeus, what a race of women hast thou given to us !
tgt_text.1684: Truly a miserable one-as are men whose city has been taken by the enemy.
tgt_text.1686: Dost thou speak ill-omened words, and that whilst touching the images ?
tgt_text.1688: Through timidity fear runs away with my tongue.
tgt_text.1690: If only thou wouldst grant a trifling boon to my request!
tgt_text.1692: Speak it as quickly as may be, and I shall quickly know.
tgt_text.1698: In company with others I will endure my appointed fate.
tgt_text.1700: This speech of thine I prefer to those others.
tgt_text.1701: Now in addition come thou outside the [precinct of] the images, and implore the gods to be our helpers in victory:
tgt_text.1702: and, after hearing my prayer, then do thou loudly chant a solemn strain of well-wishing, the cry accompanying sacrifice [pre- scribed by] Hellenic custom, an encouragement to friends, removing thus their fear of the foe.
tgt_text.1703: And I to the tutelary gods of the country, both those that haunt the plain and those that watch over the market, and to the waters of Dircè—nor do I leave out Ismenus—do vow that we, when things have gone well and the city is saved, drenching with blood of sheep the altars of the gods and sacrificing bulls in their honour, will set up trophies;
tgt_text.1704: and upon the sacred buildings will I hang in front of the temples spear-won spoils of foemen, the vestments of our enemies.
tgt_text.1706: Make such thy prayer to the gods, not indulging in lamentation;
tgt_text.1707: nor with vain and threatening bluster, for no whit the more by that wilt thou escape thy destiny.
tgt_text.1708: For my part, I will go and station six champions against six with myself as seventh, as opponents to the foe in heroic style, at the seven exits from the walls, ere messengers in hot haste and flying rumour of report arrive and set us on fire by [the urgency of] the need.
tgt_text.1712: but through fear my spirit is not lulled to rest.
tgt_text.1713: Near to my heart, anxieties are kindling terror of the folk around our walls, as a timid dove dreads on behalf of her nestlings snakes dangerous to her brood.
tgt_text.1714: For some are advancing in full force and close array against the towers, (what will become of me!) and some are hurling pebbles at our citizens exposed on both sides.
tgt_text.1715: By every means, 0 gods of Zeus' race, rescue the city and host of Cadmus' line.
tgt_text.1716: What land better than this will ye get in exchange, if ye abandon to its foes this deep-soiled country and the water of Dircè, most healthful of all draughts that Poseidon the encompasser of earth sends up, and the children of Tethys ?
tgt_text.1717: Therefore, 0 tutelary gods, by sending upon1 those outside our towers disaster with slaughter of men and flinging away of shields, earn for yourselves praise in the eyes of these citizens;
tgt_text.1718: and be ye securely established as rescuers of the city [in response] to our prayers.
tgt_text.1719: For piteous it is to send to the Under-world, a prize of the spear reduced to slavery, an ancient city dishonourably brought to ruin in crumbling dust by an Argive warrior through the will of the gods;
tgt_text.1720: and that these women should be dragged away as captives, young and old (ah me, ah me!) by their hair, like horses by their manes, with tearing of their robes about them.
tgt_text.1721: The city groans being made desolate, as the captives of mingled speech 1 are carried away.
tgt_text.1722: I anticipate with dread a grievous fate.
tgt_text.1723: Pitiful indeed it is that maidens of marriageable age, before the rites which cull the flower of virginity, should pass from their homes on a hated journey,-what say you ?
tgt_text.1724: I count that one who perishes has far better fortune than this,-for numerous (ah me!) when a city is captured are the ills it suffers.
tgt_text.1725: One drags off another, slays, sets fire to parts of the town :
tgt_text.1726: all the citadel is murky with smoke.
tgt_text.1727: Ares in frenzy, subduer of men, is the inspirer—desecrating all ties of piety.
tgt_text.1728: Tumults arise in the citadel, and the towered circumvalla- tion 2 is pushed close to the town ;
tgt_text.1729: and man by man is slain with the spear;
tgt_text.1730: and wailing cries, choked in blood, of young children resound, cries of infants at the breast.
tgt_text.1731: And there are plunderings, near allied to dispersed flights:
tgt_text.1732: pillager meets with pillager, and the empty-handed calls to the empty-handed wishing to have a partner, greedy each of them for a share neither less nor [only] equal.
tgt_text.1733: What after this is it natural to conjecture ?
tgt_text.1734: And fruits of the earth of all sorts strewn upon the ground cause sorrow as they meet the eye;
tgt_text.1735: and sad are the faces of the waiting-maids.
tgt_text.1736: Freely is earth's produce swept a medley away in valueless streams.
tgt_text.1737: And young female slaves have new sorrows, unhappy in their union by right of capture with some victorious warrior, since now that the foe is conqueror they must expect a nightly office to come, increasing 3 still their tearful griefs.
tgt_text.1739: The scout, my friends, is bringing us, as it seems to me, some fresh information;
tgt_text.1740: urging in haste the forwarding axles of his feet.
tgt_text.1742: Lo! the king himself, son of Oedipus, is here at just the moment to hear the scout's report;
tgt_text.1743: and haste makes his gait, too, uneven.
tgt_text.1745: I can tell from full observation the doings of our opponents, and how each has drawn his allotted station at our gates.
tgt_text.1746: Tydeus already at the gate of Proetus is fretting -yet the seer forbids him to cross the Ismenus, since the sacrifices are not propitious.
tgt_text.1747: But Tydeus in wild excitement and eager for the fray is uttering sounds like hissings of a snake in the mid-day heat;
tgt_text.1748: and assails with taunts the seer, wise Oecleides, that ‘ out of cowardice he is shrinking before [the approach of] death and battle.'
tgt_text.1749: Shouting such words, he shakes three overshadowing crests, the hairy plume of his helmet;
tgt_text.1750: and from beneath his shield bells of wrought brass are making a terrifying din.
tgt_text.1751: And upon his shield he bears a vaunting device as follows-a sky fashioned ablaze with stars;
tgt_text.1752: and in the middle of the shield a brilliant full moon, most august of the stars, the eye of Night, stands out conspicuous.
tgt_text.1753: In such wild exultation, with armour of boastful device, he is shouting on the river-bank;
tgt_text.1754: , longing for the combat, like a horse fighting against the bit in his impatience who chafes as he hears 2 the trumpet-call.
tgt_text.1755: Whom wilt thou station to oppose this champion?
tgt_text.1756: Who, when the bolts of the gate of Proetus are withdrawn, can be trusted to defend it?
tgt_text.1758: At no man's fancy costume shall I be frightened.
tgt_text.1760: crests and bell hurt not without a spear-thrust.
tgt_text.1761: And as for this Night glittering with stars which thou sayest occupies the sky upon his shield, perhaps the conceit1 may prove prophetic to one I know.
tgt_text.1762: For if in death night descends upon his eyes, then to him that bears it this high-vaunting device will prove itself rightly and correctly named, and he himself shall make this insolence prophetic against himself.
tgt_text.1763: Now against Tydeus I will station the brave son of Astacus here, as defender of the gate,-a man of right noble birth who worships the throne of Honour and detests arrogant speech;
tgt_text.1764: for idle in mean actions, but no coward, is he wont to be;
tgt_text.1765: and from the Sown Heroes, they whom Ares spared, his stock is sprung, and truly a native of this soil is he,—Melanippus.
tgt_text.1766: The issue will Ares with his dice determine.
tgt_text.1767: Justice how- ever, his near kinswoman, makes him her champion to keep off the foeman's spear from the mother who bore him.
tgt_text.1769: May the gods grant that our champion gains the victory, who in a just cause speeds forth to fight for his city.
tgt_text.1770: Yet I fear on behalf of my friends to look on deaths by bloodshed.
tgt_text.1772: To him may the gods so grant to be victorious.
tgt_text.1773: But at the Electran gate Capaneus is stationed by lot;
tgt_text.1774: a giant this man—taller than the one before mentioned ;
tgt_text.1775: -and his boasting words betoken thoughts unsuited to a mortal, and he threatens terrible things (which may the gods not bring to pass!) against our defences;
tgt_text.1776: for he declares that, whether Heaven wills it or wills it not, he will sack our town, and not even the wrath of Zeus striking down upon the plain in his path shall restrain him.
tgt_text.1777: Lightning flashes and thunderbolts he compares to the warmth of the noon- tide sun.
tgt_text.1778: And he bears for device a naked man carrying fire, and a torch ready for action is blazing in his hands;
tgt_text.1779: and in letters of gold he announces, ' I will burn the city.'
tgt_text.1780: To a man like this do thou send-who shall engage with him, who shall abide without a tremor so vaunting a warrior ?
tgt_text.1782: To this advantage of ours1 [in his over- confidence] yet another is added [in his impiety].
tgt_text.1784: Of a foolish mind surely his own tongue is true evidence against a man.
tgt_text.1785: Capaneus utters threats, prepared to carry them out,-and, slighting the gods as he exercises his tongue in foolish exultation, sends, though a mortal, swelling words ringing up to Zeus,—yet am I confident that against him will justly come the fiery thunderbolt in no way to be compared to the warmth of the noontide sun.
tgt_text.1786: And against him, for all his insolence of speech, is ranged a champion fiery of spirit, stalwart Polyphontes,.one to be relied upon as a guard, by favour of protecting Artemis and with aid of the other gods.

tgt_text.5310: Call blessings from the earth and from the ocean-dew, and from the heaven;
tgt_text.5311: pray that the blowing winds may pass over the land with sunny breathe that increase of the earth and cattle may not faint with time but flow on ever for my citizens in streaming plenty, and that seed of human-kind may be preserved.
tgt_text.5312: But may your fruitfulness be rather shown in the righteous;
tgt_text.5313: 2 for, like a shepherder of herbs, I love the unrepented sort of these just men here present.
tgt_text.5315: These blessings are for thee to give, and in the glorious tournaments of war my heart shall never rest content but I will make this city famous in the world as a victorious town.
tgt_text.5317: I will accept the Union of home with Pallas, and will not reject a City which even Zeus Omnipotent and Ares hold as a strong fortress of the Gods, the precious jewel that protects the altars of Hellenic Deities.
tgt_text.5318: For her I make my prayer, with all benignant auspices, that life's enjoyments may be made to teem forth for her from the Earth in bounteous plenty by the beaming radiance of the Sun.1Ath.
tgt_text.5319: It is in kindness to my Citizens that I am acting thus, in planting here among them Spirits so powerful and so ill-appeased;
tgt_text.5320: for to their lot hath fallen the disposal of all things touching Man;
tgt_text.5321: but he that meets with them in angry mood 2 knows not from what quarter come the blows that strike his life :
tgt_text.5322: it is the offences of his forefathers that arrest and hale him before these, and Destruction silently, for all his vaunt, with deadly anger crumbles him to dust.
tgt_text.5324: May breath of evil never blow to hurt her trees- 'tis by my grace-and may the scorching heat that nips the budding eyes of plants refrain from trespassing beyond the boundaries of its region;
tgt_text.5325: 3 may no drear disease of sterile blight proceed against her;
tgt_text.5326: may Pan make her flocks to thrive at the appointed season4 with twinned increase, and may there be rich offspring of the boon Earth's wealth to pay reward for Spirits' gift of Treasure-trove.5Ath.
tgt_text.5327: O hear, ye Warders of my City, how great blessings she doth seal you surely-for the Queen Erinys hath great power both with the Immortals and with those of Earth below, and in the affairs of Man most manifestly their dispose is absolute, to some affording songs of gladness, and to others life that is a blur of tears.
tgt_text.5329: To all untimely sudden deaths I cry A vaunt!
tgt_text.5330: and may the lives of her young lovely maidens win a husband -grant that, Ye whose proper power it is,1 and Ye, O Heavenly Fates, our Sisters by one Mother,2 Spirits whose dispense is pure, participants in every home, at every season weighty with most righteous presence, everywhere most honoured among Gods of Heaven.
tgt_text.5332: My heart is glad to hear them seal these blessings on my land so zealously;
tgt_text.5333: and I am grateful to Persuasion's eyes for looking with their favourable guidance on my tongue when pleading with these Powers that were so wrathfully averted from me:
tgt_text.5334: nay, but Zeus of Eloquence prevailed, and our contention for the good is crowned with triumph absolutely.
tgt_text.5336: May Faction, that insatiable source of evil, never rage within this city;
tgt_text.5337: never may the dust drink up the purple blood of citizens in anger3 and for revenge seize greedily upon retaliating deaths of civic blood:
tgt_text.5338: may their exchanges rather be of joy for joy with sentiments of love in common, and dislike with one consent;
tgt_text.5339: therein lies the cure for many human ills.
tgt_text.5341: 0 have they not the judgment to find out the path of speaking fair?
tgt_text.5343: From these Shapes of Terror I foresee great gain in stores for you, my Citizens:
tgt_text.5344: for if ye keep good feeling between them and you, and hold them in high honour, ye shall surely shine conspicuous in the world for guiding land and city in the path of upright justice.
tgt_text.5347: I wish you, joy in due apportionment of wealth, joy, 0 ye people of the City, blest with friendship of the Virgin who is seated near to Zeus,1 learners of wise-minded- ness in time;
tgt_text.5348: and shelterers beneath the wings of Pallas, ye are viewed as sacred by the Father.
tgt_text.5351: But I must now go before you to point out your chambers by the sacred light of these your Escort:
tgt_text.5352: 2 come ye now, and with these solemn sacrifices being sped below the earth, what is harmful to the country keep down there suppressed,3 and what is profitable send aloft to make my city triumph !-Lead on now, ye Sons of Cranaus that possess this City, lead these Denizens upon their way, and in the hearts of the Citizens may there be good will for good received.
tgt_text.5354: Joy to you, again I say it, joy, all ye dwellers in the City, mortal and immortal both.
tgt_text.5355: While ye possess the City of Pallas and keep my Denizenship sacred, your life's fortunes shall give you nothing to complain of.
tgt_text.5357: I thank you for the terms of these your benedictions, and will now conduct you with the light of blazing torches to that nether subterranean House, with ministers that are the guards of mine own image;
tgt_text.5359: for it should be the eye of all the land of Theseus that shall arrive,2 a noble troop of maidens, wives, and aged dames.
tgt_text.5360: Deck them with scarlet over-cloaks of honour, and let the blazing light move on;
tgt_text.5361: that so the good will of these new dwellers in the land may be shown henceforth in blessings of fine Manhood.

tgt_text.0: ÆSCHYLUS, son of Euphoriou, was born at Eleusis, B.C. 525..
tgt_text.1: His early employment to watch the grapes in a vineyard is traditionally reported to have led to the devclopement of his tragic genius, and possibly to some less excusable propensities of his character, in which the god Baccnus was equally con­ cerned.
tgt_text.2: He first appeared as a tragedian in B.C. 499, with Chœrilus and Pratinas for his competitors.
tgt_text.3: In B.C. 490, he distinguished himself at the battle of Marathon, in company with his brothers Cynegeirus and Ameinias.
tgt_text.4: In B.C. 484, he gained his first tragic victory, and in B.C. 480, he fought at Salamis:
tgt_text.5: thus, as Schlegel1 observes, “ he flourished in the very freshness and vigour of Grecian freedom, and a proud sense of the glorious struggle by which it was won, seems to have animated him and his poetry."
tgt_text.6: This warlike vein is con­ spicuous in the “ Persæ” and “ Seven against Thebes," while the " Agamemnon" is replete with pathetic illustrations of the toils, dangers, and sufferings, of a soldier's life.
tgt_text.7: His journeys into Sicily involve some intricate questions, but the received opinion seems to settle his first visit in B.C. 4G8, immediately after his defeat by Sophocles, and he pro­ bably spent some time there, if the use of Sicilian words in his later plays may be adduced as an argument.
tgt_text.8: The other journey was probably ten years after, B.C. 458, and, as Müller thinks, was undertaken in consequence of the aristocratic notions so freely expressed in his " Eumenides," which wert too openly opposed to the interests of Pericles' party, ther. in tIll ascendant, to render Athens a safe abode for our poet Other accounts state that a charge of impiety was the real cause of his second departure, and that he only escaped the fury of the populace, through the intervention of the Areopagus.
tgt_text.9: His death took place at Gela, B.C. 456.
tgt_text.10: The story is, that an eagle having mistaken his bald head for a stone, dropped a tortoise upon it in order to break the shell, and that the blow proved fatal.
tgt_text.11: There seems, however, little doubt but that our poet died in the ordinary course of nature, as his ad­ vanced age would render probable.
tgt_text.12: The number of plays written by Æschylus is doubtful, but, as in the case of Sophocles, seven only have survived the ravages of time.
tgt_text.13: Among these seven we are fortunate
tgt_text.14: In possessing a complete trilogy, consisting of the " Agamem­ non," “Choephoræ,” and “Eumenides.”
tgt_text.15: The remaining plays are the " Prometheus Bound," the “ Seven Chiefs against Thebes," the " Persians," and the " Suppliants.
tgt_text.16: "In criticising the plays of Æschylus, due regard must be had to the state in which Æschylus found the drama, and to the difference between his earlier and later works, as far as the existing specimens allow us to judge.
tgt_text.17: When we are told that Æschylus formed the dialogue of the Athenian stage, by adding a second actor, it is evident that the preceding dramas must have consisted of little else than a recitative and chorus alternately following each other.
tgt_text.18: The single actor probably detailed some legend possessing a mythological or local interest, while the chorus relieved the monotony by songs and dances connected with the subject.
tgt_text.19: If we consider the earliest specimens of our own drama, we shall find the dialogue heavy, and consisting of long para­ graphs, whilst the more modern stage limits these lengthy speeches to narrative, argument, or soliloquy.
tgt_text.20: But in the "Suppliants" of Æschylus, (which some scholars consider the most ancient specimen of the Greek drama that has descended to us in a complete form,) we shall find that the chorus are really the chief personages in the piece, and, as AEschylus is considered to have limited the functions of the chorus, it follows that the single actor was rather subservient to carrying on the story, than the hero of it.
tgt_text.21: And this agrees with Aristotle's account, that Æschylus " introduced an actor of first parts'," evidently shewing that the histrionic abilities previously required in the actor were of an inferior order.
tgt_text.22: Throughout the whole play of the " Suppliants," the pathos rests entirely with the chorus, the speeches of Danaus and the king are quiet and didactic, and even the herald lacks the haughtiness with which such persons are elsewhere invested.
tgt_text.23: Setting aside the chorus, the whole play exhibits a dead level of moral common places and mythical details.
tgt_text.24: It might indeed be read and performed "with characters omitted."
tgt_text.25: As far as the corrupt state of the choruses will allow us to judge, they were genial, brilliant, and graceful, but the very nature of a chorus destroyed all individualisation.
tgt_text.26: Their griefs, joys, and emotions, were common to all their number;
tgt_text.27: there were so many heroines, that there was no heroine.
tgt_text.28: There is another feature in the Supplices, which points to its extreme antiquity, and that is, its undramatic character.
tgt_text.29: In the first chorus we are told as much as we know at the end of the play.
tgt_text.30: Like the prologues prefixed to the comedies of Terence (unnecessary, as the plot is always the same), the opening chorus contains the whole argument of the piece.
tgt_text.31: The Danaïdes have fled from Egypt to avoid the lawless love of their kinsmen, they crave protection, are admonished to behave themselves;
tgt_text.32: they obtain protection, and, it is to be hoped, follow their father's advice.
tgt_text.33: There is, in fact, some­ thing half comic in the whole story, and the effect could only have been heightened by a concluding play in the trilogy (if there was any1), in which their punishment should have been so before the eyes of the spectator, with real tubs and real water.
tgt_text.34: After what has been said on the subject of the " Suppliants,” the reader will perhaps be surprised to find that Schlegel considers the " Persæ,” “ both in point of choice of subject, and the manner of handling it, undoubtedly the most im­ perfect of all the extant tragedies of this poet."
tgt_text.35: Æschylus certainly laboured under the same disadvantages as Lucan and Silius Italicus, in having chosen a subject too near his own time to possess a mythical interest, and too much de­ pending upon narrative to be truly dramatic.
tgt_text.36: But he suc­ cessfully appealed to the feelings of the audience, who doubt­ less listened to this panegyric upon Athens with as much satisfaction as an English audience applauded the braggart prologues " spoken upon occasion," during the last century.
tgt_text.37: There is too great a desire in German critics to elevate the standard of Athenian refinement.
tgt_text.38: The conclusion of the " Persians " savours too much of ridicule, to excite any high feelings of commiseration, and this play, like the “ Seven against Thebes," ought to have ended soone .
tgt_text.39: But in the episodes Æschylus has shown great power.
tgt_text.40: The prevailing notion throughout the play is of a deity favouring the Athenians, and overthrowing the haughty yoke of the Persians.
tgt_text.41: The atheistic impiety of Xerxes is hinted at, and his too-late repentance is an instance of the fatalism found throughout the "Agamemnon," and pervading the Æschylean drama.
tgt_text.42: The piety of the Greeks, on the contrary, is power­ fully contrasted, and the deity is accordingly represented as “ beginning the fight."
tgt_text.43: This description of the sea-fight is wonderfully animated, and could be written only by an eye- witness of the victory of Salamis, while the description of the fate of the miserable remnants of the Persian army, as de­ tailed by the messenger, is in the highest degree graphic.
tgt_text.44: Nor was the evocation of Darius less pleasing to an Athe­ nian mind.
tgt_text.45: The ancient prophecies of Bacis and others, which, although they might refer to mythical events, were nevertheless greedily seized upon, and applied to the present moment, and the recognition of ancient local traditions by supernatural powers, was an agreeable sacrifice to the vanity of the Athenians.
tgt_text.46: Every man would have exclaimed with Hamlet:
tgt_text.48: It is an honest ghost ——Nay, Æschylus has excited a feeling of pity for the defeat of the Persians, by the amiable dignity with which he has in­ vested the character of their former lord.
tgt_text.49: The quiet, sub­ stantial steadiness of Darius is the most powerful satire upon the intemperance of their subsequent ruler that can be ima­ gined, and the whole evocation is invested with a mystical solemnity that makes uf forget its ideality.
tgt_text.50: Many critics consider the “ Persians ” as the earliest of the extant plays of Æschylus, but for the reasons above stated, I am inclined to give the higher antiquity to the “ Suppliants.
tgt_text.51: "If the “ Seven against Thebes" was connected with the “ Eleusinians," as Müller thinks, I scarcely believe that Æschylus would have ended with an anticlimax, by intro­ ducing the lamentations of Antigone and Ismena over their fallen brothers.
tgt_text.52: When this critic says, " this concluding scene points as distinctly as the end of the Choephoræ to the subject of a new piece, which was doubtless the Eleusinians1,’ " he asserts too much.
tgt_text.53: In the first place, it is clear from Plutarch (Thes. p. 14, A.).
tgt_text.54: that the burial of the chieftains was effected by Theseus under a truce, not by violence.
tgt_text.55: If, therefore, matters were amicably arranged, why should Antigone be “ closely connected with this subject.”
tgt_text.57: Muller has told us a great deal that we do not know, but has over­ looked the only point that Plutarch tells us respecting the “ Eleusinians," which, unfortunately contradicts his whole theory.
tgt_text.58: We might as well say that the threats of the Mycenian elders, at the end of the " Agamemnon,” neces­ sarily required the " Choephoræ,” to open with their revolt, as that, because Antigone threatens to bury her brother, Æschylus was obliged to make her do so in another play, of which all our knowledge only proves the contrary.
tgt_text.59: The theory of tetralogy has been carried much too far.
tgt_text.60: The “ Seven against Thebes" is doubtless an early play, and is as undramatic as the “ Persians."
tgt_text.61: But the high tone of true Grecian chivalry which reigns throughout, the splendid individuality of the characters, despite their one common feature of physical valour, is equal to anything, even in Æschylus.
tgt_text.62: The description of each warrior is not only a physical and heroic, but an ethical picture
tgt_text.63: The high-souled Amphiaraus, whose destiny led him to that death his wisdom foresaw, whose fate impelled him to that society his sense shrunk from, is pathetically contrasted with the mad boldness of the other chieftains.-his religion with their impiety-his modesty with their idle vaunting—his wisdom with their recklessness.
tgt_text.64: And when Eteocles praises him, we almost forget that he too lies under the ban of fate.
tgt_text.65: So good does Eteocles seem by his praise of the good.
tgt_text.66: In allusion to the question of a connexion between dramas, it may be worth while to observe the different degrees of fatalism that influence the minds of the two brothers in this play, and in the “ (Edipus at Colonus " of Sophocles.
tgt_text.67: Poly­ nices, in the latter play, is presented to us as the heart- broken fugitive, the wandering victim of a father's curse, softened by misfortune, and seeking to palliate the wrath of his destiny.
tgt_text.68: But in the Eteocles of JEschylus, there is no compunction.
tgt_text.69: He remembers the curse of his aged sire, and speaks even with affection of the man who had banned his lawless life by a paternal anathema.
tgt_text.70: But he seeks not to avert the doom.
tgt_text.71: Stern, uncompromising, he will meet the man he must slay, by whom he must himself fall.
tgt_text.72: Still, as Sophocles has softened the character of Polynices till he almost obtains our pity, so has Æschylus heightened that of Eteocles with sentiments of temperate prudence and un­ daunted courage, till he deserves it;

tgt_text.74: shall now proceed to the consideration of the “ Prome­ neus,” the sublimest poem, and simplest tragedy of antiquity.
tgt_text.75: 1 have one motive in doing so, in reference to that great triad of tragedies, the “ Oresteia," and that is to show the similar aristocratic spirit that pervades the whole of the four plays.
tgt_text.76: The Titan majesty of mankind had been infringed by the new gods of Olympus, and Prometheus appeared as their protector, the assertor of their rights.
tgt_text.77: Opposed to a new aristocracy, he was still the supreme power of the old one.
tgt_text.78: In the true spirit of the old aristocracy he laboured for the benefit of his weaker dependants.
tgt_text.79: The Olympian gods, like the parvenus of Aristotle1, are everywhere represented as oppressing mankind, and each other.
tgt_text.80: Moreover, Prometheus represents the intellectual ascendancy of mankind over the creation, the power of moral progress in opposition to phy­ sical strength and conventional resources.
tgt_text.81: The imprudence of Jove is hereafter to destroy that power, in the haughtiness of which he had thought fit to spurn the god of wisdom from him.
tgt_text.82: Much as I am disinclined to allegorical interpreters and interpretations, much as I dislike the tediousness of an Eustathius or the barbarism of a Fulgentius, still the “Pro­ metheus" of Æschylus cannot but seem a magnificent imper­ sonation of mind struggling against circumstances, intellect against force, providence against fate.
tgt_text.83: And the very fatalism of this play is pleasing.
tgt_text.84: Unlike the gloomy demon that lurks over the ill-fated house of Mycenæ, unlike the Fates that but exchange death for revenge, Prometheus is ever cheered by the triumphant prospect before him.
tgt_text.85: As he foresaw his present troubles, so he even names the time of their termination.
tgt_text.86: His very philanthropy, his inability to do further good, force from him the groan of the hero, but, as the good man meets death, so does he meet pain—conscious that there is something yet to come.
tgt_text.87: The introduction of Io is perfctly agreeable to Aristotle's idea of Episode, and enables us to learn the deeds of Pro­ metheus, and to test his powers of prescience.
tgt_text.88: Moreover, Prometheus and Io are both victims to the power of Zeus, both await their relief from his downfall.
tgt_text.89: The pathetic description of Io’s fall, her exclusion from the home of her sorrowing sire, her phantom-stricken wanderings over earth and sea, are all depictured with a power that proves how Æschylus could touch the tenderest, as well as the most lofty emotions of the human soul.
tgt_text.90: Muller has entered, with some ability, iuto the question of the discrepancy between the character of Zeus as pourtrayed in this play, and in the later works of our poet.
tgt_text.91: I grant that the tyrannical Zeus of this play is unlike the mild potentate, "who guides men in the ways of wisdom1,” or the great Zeus in heaven2," whose aid the fatherless may implore with confidence against their oppressors, but I do not see the necessity of reconciling the inconsistency.
tgt_text.92: If Æschylus could create a conception, he might also depart from it.
tgt_text.93: Zeus was as necessarily the tyrant in the Titan world, as he was the mild governor of things in the heroic ages.
tgt_text.94: But Müller has rightly observed, that this discrepancy is partly reconciled by the fact that Prometheus everywhere appears in the light of an offender against the " powers that be," too proud to reve­ rence Adrasteia.
tgt_text.95: Like Antigone, he is relatively guilty, In offending against ruling authorities;
tgt_text.96: like her, he is abstract­ edly right.
tgt_text.97: The sin of both is the sin of time and place, not of principle.
tgt_text.98: Shelley, whose whole poetry is deeply imbued with the mysterious power of AEschylus, has imitated the imagery of this play with a success proving that a man must be a poet to truly appreciate Æschylus.
tgt_text.99: It is to be regretted that this true genius, (like Knowles, so often disgraced by imitators.) never translated any productions of the Greek drama, with the single exception of the Satyric “ Cyclops " of Euripides.
tgt_text.100: He has invested his Prometheus with all the placid grandeur of the deity, all the tenderness of the good man.
tgt_text.101: To say that he imitates, in the modern sense, is to say nothing-to feel that the spirit of Æsehylus has passed into the mind of Shelley, is the fairest praise that can be awarded.
tgt_text.102: But the picturesque scenery of Shelley's painting is the marvellous feature of the play.
tgt_text.103: The Indian Caucasus, with its ice-bound rocks, and gloomy prospect of the world spread beneath it;
tgt_text.104: the sea, " heaven's ever-changing shadow," and the giant, grotesque glaciers, lost in the dim, chilled atmosphere, form a picture that the mind of Æschylus could conceive, but the hand of the Grecian painter could not imitate.
tgt_text.105: But circum­ stantial comparison will lead us too much away from the main subject.
tgt_text.106: The legend of Prometheus lives in the poetry of Æsehylus and Shelley.
tgt_text.107: The power of one poet can scarcely be measured but by the equality of the other.
tgt_text.108: The mention of scenery suggests a question of much æsthetic interest, namely, how far the Athenian artist could realise the conceptions of the poet.
tgt_text.109: In the " Prometheus " such an attempt must have been a failure.
tgt_text.110: Setting aside the question of the place of Prometheus' suffering, the poetry draws upon larger resources than the Athenian scene-painter could have possessed.
tgt_text.111: The architectural delineations of the fronts of palaces and other buildings, which usually formed the scene of the drama, were easily executed, and in a country pos­ sessing the finest models for imitation, were doubtless unsur­ passed for effect and correctness.
tgt_text.112: But the occasional land­ seape paintings on the periaktoi must have been rude, and even grotesque.
tgt_text.113: The most finished frescoes we possess arc totally devoid of any attempt to realise nature, the fragments of encaustic paintings are confined to the human form, and such objects as require no perspective;
tgt_text.114: and if we regard the paintings of the earliest Florentine artists, which sprung from the imitation of the latest Greek, improved by Cimabue, Giotto, and a few others, we shall find nothing to justify the supposition that the Greeks ever attained to any excellence in landscape painting.
tgt_text.115: The knowledge of aërial perspective, upon which all the realization of the "Prometheus" would depend, is scarcely three centuries old, and if we consider how long our own stage wanted such scenic accessories, we cannot be surprised at the deficiency of the Greeks.
tgt_text.116: The decorations of the Athenian stage were probably confined to costume and architectural embellishment.
tgt_text.117: Moreover, the fact that the plays were always represented in the day-time must have robbed them of all the exquisite illusion pro­ duced by the use and combinations of artificial lights.
tgt_text.118: Such being the case, how great was the power of the poet, who could so successfully place nature before his hearers by words only!
tgt_text.119: The testimony of the didascalia shows that the " Agamem­ non," " Choephorae," and " Eumenides," were performed at the same time, together with a satyric drama called the Pro­ teus.
tgt_text.120: We are, therefore, justified in considering them as forming a trilogy, although I doubt whether the “Oresteia1” is a fit name for the trilogy, when Orestes is only indirectly mentioned in the first and principal play.
tgt_text.121: Nor is the con­ nection between the three plays so exact as that which exists in the " King CEdipus," " CEdipus at Colonus," and " Anti­ gone " of Sophocles, which we know did not form a trilogy.
tgt_text.122: At all events, the thlee plays form the grandest dramatic work of antiquity.
tgt_text.123: It is true, we do not find the lights and shades of character pourtrayed with the delicate finish of Sophocles, nor is the character of Orestes invested with all the interest of which it might seem capable.
tgt_text.124: But Æschylus, unlike the modern adaptors, who write a piece for two actors in as many days, never sacrificed the play to enhance the character.
tgt_text.125: In a play like the " Prometheus," the hero was necessarily the leading character;
tgt_text.126: but in the Agamemno­ nian history there were no less than four great characters,-- Agamemnon, Orestes, Clytæmnestra, and Cassandra.
tgt_text.127: Nor are the minor parts of the Watchman, the Herald, and Ægisthus, devoid of strongly marked individuality, while Minerva, as Muller has remarked, may almost be considered as the leading character in the “ Eumenides.
tgt_text.128: "This attention to the minor characters is almost peculiar to Æschylus.
tgt_text.129: In the extant dramas of Sophocles we every­ where discover a greater amount of subordination to one leading.

tgt_text.131: Sophocles forms an abstraction, and not only embodies it in the character of the hero, but sacrifices all surrounding objects to the general conception.
